Incorrect: A colleague of mine wrote, “Institutions need to be able to collect and collate data in a centralized tool, which is easily accessible and can be mined to inform data-analytics activities.” I corrected it to “Institutions need to be able to collect and collate data in a centralized tool that is easily accessible and can be mined to inform data-analytics activities,” but she disagrees with the edit. Incorrect: Adverbs that are weak substitutes for a vivid verb
Correct: The stranger walked threateningly toward us.BETTER: The stranger stalked toward us.
Suggestion: EXAMPLE

Incorrect: Stalling phrases like
Correct: The sun’s reflection seemed to glisten and waver on the water.BETTER: The sun’s reflection glistened and wavered on the water.
Suggestion: EXAMPLE

Incorrect: Meaningless
Correct: He just climbed to the top and fell asleep.BETTER: He climbed to the top and fell asleep.
Suggestion: EXAMPLE

Incorrect: It as a sentence opener
Correct: It was the comment about the dog that enabled the detective to solve the case.BETTER: The comment about the dog enabled the detective to solve the case.
Suggestion: EXAMPLE

Incorrect: The titles of novels, long poems, movies, and television series are italicized.
Correct: British usage prefers single quotation marks (e.g., ‘Ulysses’).
Suggestion: “Ulysses” (short poem of 73 lines)“Deus ex Machina” (episode title of television series “When You Wish upon a Star” (song)Note

Incorrect: Arizona Prison Privatization Proposal Doesn’t Jive with Market
Correct: But my opinion about that doesn’t jibe with everyone else’s opinion.
Suggestion: Arizona Prison Privatization Proposal Doesn’t Jibe with Market

Incorrect: If your child is hurling his own silly jibes at the teaser, then it’s a mutual thing.
Correct: Put-downs, slurs, gibes, and innuendo of all kinds are never purposeless or harmless.
Suggestion: If your child is hurling his own silly gibes at the teaser, then it’s a mutual thing.

Incorrect: Running consistently every day, the workouts steadily became easier.
Correct: A person must be specified as the doing the activity.
Suggestion: Running consistently every day, he found that the workouts steadily became easier.
Label: Grammar -Dangling Participles

Incorrect: Studying for her degree, there were times when she felt like giving up.
Correct: A phrase containing an expletive, or filler, such as there in “there were” is not the subject of the sentence; an actor must be specified at the head of the main clause.
Suggestion: Studying for her degree, she felt, at times, like giving up.
Label: Grammar -Dangling Participles

Incorrect: Rolling down the hill, my eyes widened as the truck came into view.
Correct: As in the first example, an actor must perform the activity.
Suggestion: Rolling down the hill, I stared with wide-open eyes as the truck came into view.
Label: Grammar -Dangling Participles

Incorrect: The Grand Canyon was the highlight, driving through the Southwest.
Correct: Even when the main clause begins the sentence, the participial phrase must name the actor.
Suggestion: The Grand Canyon was the highlight as we drove through the Southwest.
Label: Grammar -Dangling Participles

Incorrect: Knowing what was at stake, I prepared myself mentally for the ordeal.
Correct: This sentence correctly begins the main clause with the actor as the subject.
Suggestion: Knowing what was at stake, I prepared myself mentally for the ordeal.
Label: Grammar -Dangling Participles

Incorrect: I walked over to the Smith’s house.
Correct: The house is occupied by the Smiths, not the Smith, so the name must be treated as a plural possessive.
Suggestion: I walked over to the Smiths’ house.
Label: Grammar -Possessives

Incorrect: Our hostess’ nerves are shot.
Correct: Words ending in “s” are not exempt from requiring an “s” after the possessive apostrophe.
Suggestion: Our hostess’s nerves are shot.
Label: Grammar -Possessives

Incorrect: I went to my aunt’s and uncle’s anniversary celebration.
Correct: When a pair of nouns is considered a single entity or group, only the second noun should be in the possessive form. (However, when two closely linked nouns are nevertheless clearly associated with distinct referents, both nouns should be in the possessive form, as in “I researched my aunt’s and uncle’s family backgrounds.”)
Suggestion: I went to my aunt and uncle’s anniversary celebration.
Label: Grammar -Possessives

Incorrect: She made it onto the girls basketball team.
Correct: When a word can take either a possessive form (in this case, girls’, as in “for girls”) or an attributive form (here, girls, as in “of girls”), the possessive form is usually more appropriate.
Suggestion: She made it onto the girls’ basketball team.
Label: Grammar -Possessives

Incorrect: I sent flowers to her on Mother’s Day.
Correct: Holiday names ending in s vary as whether they are attributive (Veterans Day), singular possessive (Saint Patrick’s Day), or plural possessive (April Fools’ Day). Celebrations of mothers and fathers are singular possessive, so this sentence is correct.
Suggestion: I sent flowers to her on Mother’s Day.
Label: Grammar -Possessives

Incorrect: In 2000, the figure was 57 percent; in 2004, 63 percent.
Correct: When a sentence consists of two parallel independent clauses but the repetition of part of the second clause is omitted because the elided phrase is implied, a semicolon should still be used despite the fact that the second clause appears not to be independent. This sentence, in which repetition of the phrase “the figure was” has been omitted between the second year and the second percentage, is correct.
Suggestion: In 2000, the figure was 57 percent; in 2004, 63 percent.
Label: Grammar -Weak-Period Semicolons

Incorrect: We have come this far, we can’t give up now.
Correct: 3.Original: Sometimes she was willing to share these with the class and to read aloud, sometimes she wanted to remove herself from class discussions.Correct : Sometimes, she was willing to share these with the class and to read aloud; sometimes, she wanted to remove herself from class discussions.
Suggestion: We have come this far; we can’t give up now.
Label: Grammar -Weak-Period Semicolons

Incorrect: He understands diffusion, osmosis, facilitated diffusion, concentration gradients, pores, and pumps; all processes essential to understanding life systems.
Correct: 5.Original: This number includes shimmering salmon blocked from their upriver migration in the Northwest; and the ancient sturgeon that once spawned in thirty-five coastal rivers from Maine to Florida and is now confined to two.Correct : This number includes shimmering salmon blocked from their upriver migration in the Northwest and the ancient sturgeon that once spawned in thirty-five coastal rivers from Maine to Florida and is now confined to two.
Suggestion: He understands diffusion, osmosis, facilitated diffusion, concentration gradients, pores, and pumps, all processes essential to understanding life systems.
Label: Grammar -Weak-Period Semicolons

Incorrect: I told my parents I wanted to transfer many times during that first semester.
Correct: The original sentence implies that the writer wished to repeatedly transfer, not that he repeatedly expressed his wish to transfer.
Suggestion: I told my parents many times during that first semester that I wanted to transfer.
Label: Grammar -Misplaced Modifiers

Incorrect: Schools are wising up to the benefits of integrating technology into classroom instruction, but access still ends with the school day for too many students.
Correct: The original syntax is not incorrect, but the sentence ends weakly.
Suggestion: Schools are wising up to the benefits of integrating technology into classroom instruction, but for too many students, access still ends with the close of the school day.
Label: Grammar -Misplaced Modifiers

Incorrect: All students should have the opportunity to be a peer mentor, not just those the teacher views as capable or who have high test scores.
Correct: In the original sentence, the parenthetical is too far removed from the subject.
Suggestion: All students, not just those the teacher views as capable or who have high test scores, should have the opportunity to be a peer mentor.
Label: Grammar -Misplaced Modifiers

Incorrect: The plan was to incorporate the school into the courthouse itself until the Oklahoma City bombing created safety concerns.
Correct: The original sentence implies that the incorporation of the schoolhouse was deliberately temporary, and that the plan was to wait until the expected bombing occurred to relocate it. However, the intended meaning is that the unexpected bombing prompted a change in the proposal.
Suggestion: Until the Oklahoma City bombing created safety concerns, the plan was to incorporate the school into the courthouse itself.
Label: Grammar -Misplaced Modifiers

Incorrect: Although DNA testing is highly effective, those involved in criminal investigations do not always use it because of its high cost.
Correct: The original placement of the modifying phrase “because of its high cost” at the end of the sentence incorrectly implies that DNA testing is always used not for its high cost but for another reason.
Suggestion: Although DNA testing is highly effective, because of its high cost, those involved in criminal investigations do not always use it.
Label: Grammar -Misplaced Modifiers

Incorrect: She is about to dive in to the pool.
Correct: One can dive in a pool (this wording refers to one’s location) or dive into a pool (this wording refers to one’s movement), but “dive in to a pool” has redundant prepositions.
Suggestion: She is about to dive into the pool.
Label: Grammar -Prepositions

Incorrect: I fell onto the platform.
Correct: This sentence was originally correct.
Suggestion: I fell onto the platform.
Label: Grammar -Prepositions

Incorrect: When we disagreed, they turned in to our enemies.
Correct: The phrase “turn in” refers to an action involving a turn, but to turn into is to change or transform. (“Turned in” remains open in the sentence “They turned us in to our enemies,” in the sense of a betrayal.)
Suggestion: When we disagreed, they turned into our enemies.
Label: Grammar -Prepositions

Incorrect: John handed the paper into his teacher.
Correct: This sentence describes the action of delivering or submitting something, for which the idiom is “hand in,” so to should be separate from in.
Suggestion: John handed the paper in to his teacher.
Label: Grammar -Prepositions

Incorrect: Do you have to hang up on every word he says?
Correct: Upon is technically correct but unnecessary in this idiomatic reference to someone giving undue attention to another’s comments — on is sufficient — but upon should be treated as two words only if the context alludes to someone ending a phone call abruptly: “Don’t hang up on me!”
Suggestion: Do you have to hang on every word he says?
Label: Grammar -Prepositions

Incorrect: To understand the subject more thoroughly, the book was read and reread.
Correct: This revision correctly identifies the readers, not the book, as the sentence’s subject.
Suggestion: They read and reread the book to understand the subject more thoroughly.
Label: Grammar -Dangling Modifiers

Incorrect: Not his favorite subject, he participated in class and completed his projects.
Correct: The original sentence erroneously equates he, rather than “the class,” with “not his favorite subject.”
Suggestion: Though the class was not his favorite one, he participated in class and completed his projects.
Label: Grammar -Dangling Modifiers

Incorrect: Always eager to participate in classroom discussions, I’m confident that her abilities will develop exponentially next year and beyond.
Correct: The original sentence incorrectly casts I as the subject.
Suggestion: She’s always eager to participate in classroom discussions, and I’m confident that her abilities will develop exponentially next year and beyond.
Label: Grammar -Dangling Modifiers

Incorrect: Being the chairman of the Hall of Fame, one of the great thrills for me was to see him inducted into the initial Hall of Fame class.
Correct: “One of the great thrills” is misidentified as the chairman.
Suggestion: For me, the chairman of the Hall of Fame, one of the great thrills was to see him inducted into the initial Hall of Fame class.
Label: Grammar -Dangling Modifiers

Incorrect: Perhaps the most combative member of Congress, Cruz’s withering criticisms of Washington have made him a champion for the conservative base.
Correct: Cruz, not his withering criticisms, is the proper subject of this sentence.
Suggestion: Cruz is perhaps the most combative member of Congress, and his withering criticisms of Washington have made him a champion for the conservative base.
Label: Grammar -Dangling Modifiers

Incorrect: I had wanted to show you where the Joneses lived.
Correct: If the Joneses no longer live at the location, the sentence is correct. But if they still live there, the past tense of the initial verb is irrelevant to the present state of their residence.
Suggestion: I had wanted to show you where the Joneses live.
Label: Grammar -Tense Shift

Incorrect: She wrote a poem that began with an apt simile.
Correct: The beginning of the poem, assuming the poem still exists, includes an apt simile, and it always will.
Suggestion: She wrote a poem that begins with an apt simile.
Label: Grammar -Tense Shift

Incorrect: Einstein supposedly said positive-feedback loops were the most impressive phenomenon in our universe.
Correct: Positive-feedback loops presumably still hold that status, so the linking verb should be in the present tense; Einstein’s evaluation is immortal even if he isn’t.
Suggestion: Einstein supposedly said positive-feedback loops are the most impressive phenomenon in our universe.
Label: Grammar -Tense Shift

Incorrect: Shortly before he died, he told me he was convinced that the only way to win was to practice.
Correct: The person expressed what he believed to be a timeless truth, not something he thought only before the time he stated his opinion.
Suggestion: Shortly before he died, he told me he was convinced that the only way to win is to practice.
Label: Grammar -Tense Shift

Incorrect: She had profound insights about how the bones of the head moved.
Correct: The movement of the bones in the head is a continuing phenomenon.
Suggestion: She had profound insights about how the bones of the head move.
Label: Grammar -Tense Shift

Incorrect: Standard English is NOT inherently superior to all other forms of English.
Correct: stimulate and inform the never-ending dialogue between prescriptivists and descriptivists.
Suggestion: [Standard English] “is an agreed norm that is selected in order to facilitate communication.” is a wonderful little book, an information-packed resource that will surely do what Horobin hopes

Incorrect: “Our idea and concept was to build a small place to entertain our friends and to have some foodies and chef friends around to create new and imaginative dishes,” co-owner chef Stefan Stiller said in a statement.
Correct: “‘Our idea and concept was to build a small place to entertain our friends and to have some foodies and chef friends around to create new and imaginative dishes,’ co-owner and chef Stefan Stiller said in a statement.” (A solidus, or slash, could be inserted to separate the terms, but this symbol should be avoided in formal writing.)
Suggestion: The conjunction  should separate two disparate identifying words or phrases associated with a person’s name

Incorrect: FBI Criminal Investigation Division Deputy Assistant Director John Smith emphasized the potential for both the industry and regulators to benefit by improving collaboration.
Correct: “John Smith, deputy assistant director of the FBI’s Criminal Investigation Division, emphasized the potential for both the industry and regulators to benefit by improving collaboration.” (Note that the job title is not capitalized when it does not precede the person’s name.)
Suggestion: When a name is preceded by a cumbersome job title, and especially if that is preceded by a reference to the entity by which the person is employed, the information is easier to read if it follows the name and the train of terms is relaxed by beginning with the job title, followed by “of the” and the entity’s name

Incorrect: The Association of Certified Anti-Money Laundering Specialists Fifteenth Annual Anti-Money Laundering and Financial Crime Conference begins on April 1.
Correct: “The fifteenth annual Anti-Money Laundering and Financial Crime Conference of the Association of Certified Anti-Money Laundering Specialists begins on April 1.” (Note that a reference to how many of these events have been held at regular intervals, such as “fifteenth annual,” is seldom part of an event’s official designation and therefore is usually not capitalized.)
Suggestion: The same approach is appropriate when the name of a component of an entity or an event presented by an entity is combined with the name of the entity

Incorrect: The researchers highlighted the follow the herd mentality the students exhibited.
Correct: “The researchers highlighted the follow-the-herd mentality the students exhibited.” (In the following sentence, “follow the herd” does not modify anything—it’s simply a verb phrase—so hyphens are not called for: “The students appeared to follow the herd in their everyday behavior.”)
Suggestion: Because the phrase “follow the herd” constitutes one idea modifying the word —and precedes the noun—the phrase should be hyphenated

Incorrect: The committee thoroughly reviewed the potential conflicts-of-interest before making a decision.
Correct: “The committee thoroughly reviewed the potential conflicts of interest before making a decision.” (If the phrase modified, and preceded, a noun—with a slight change to singular form for the first word— hyphenation would be correct, as in, “The conflict-of-interest implications are troublesome.”)
Suggestion: Here, a phrase is hyphenated unnecessarily. “Conflicts of interest” is simply a noun phrase; it does not collectively modify anything, so no linking of the words is necessary

Incorrect: The agency’s structure violates the constitutional separation of powers doctrine.
Correct: “The agency’s structure violates the constitutional separation-of-powers doctrine.” ( modifies but is not part of the modifying phrase, so it is not attached.)
Suggestion: Here, a noun phrase in the “(blank) of (blank)” form serves to modify a noun, thus transforming to a phrasal adjective. Because the three words combine to form an idea and precede the noun they refer to, they should be hyphenated

Incorrect: Her manager was none-too-pleased to see her arriving late for the second time in one week.
Correct: “Her manager was none too pleased to see her arriving late for the second time in one week.” (However, it should be hyphenated in a sentence such as “Her none-too-pleased manager watched her arrive late for the second time in one week,” because the phrase “none too pleased” precedes the noun it modifies.)
Suggestion: This idiomatic phrase represents a single idea, but because it does not immediately precede the noun it applies to, hyphenation is not appropriate

Incorrect: We apparently will be informed on a need to know basis.
Correct: “We apparently will be informed on a need-to-know basis.”
Suggestion: Here, “need to know,” which, if it were to stand alone (as in “You don’t need to know”), would not require hyphens, merits them because the words together describe the type of basis in question, so the phrase serves as a phrasal adjective

Incorrect: Three of those assembly members face a tough reelection in a Republican heavy district or represent the economically hard hit Central Valley.
Correct: “Three of those assembly members face a tough reelection in a Republican-heavy district or represent the economically hard-hit Central Valley.”
Suggestion: A lack of hyphenation in the phrase “Republican heavy district” prompts the reading “a heavy district inhabited by Republicans,” but the phrase means “a district populated mostly by Republicans,” so the phrase “Republican heavy,” as a phrasal adjective modifying , should be hyphenated; the same rule applies for the final phrase

Incorrect: The objective is to enhance focus and character work on a scene to scene basis.
Correct: “The objective is to enhance focus and character work on a .” (However, just as one would write “a district heavy in Republicans” or “the Central Valley was hard hit,” the phrasal adjective should not be hyphenated when it follows the noun, as in “we worked on the script scene to scene” (or, better, “scene by scene”).
Suggestion: The phrase “scene to scene” modifies , so it should be hyphenated

Incorrect: A weary customer said, “This is a serious shop until you drop situation, and I am dropping.”
Correct: “A weary customer said, ‘This is a serious shop-until-you-drop situation, and I am dropping.’” If that train of four hyphenated words seems too cumbersome, enclose it in single quotation marks: “This is a serious ‘shop until you drop’ situation, and I am dropping.”
Suggestion: What kind of a situation is it? One in which the customer shops until he or she drops. The idiomatic phrase “shop until you drop” is a phrasal adjective modifying , so it should be hyphenated

Incorrect: The anti-immigration group solicited signatures for their petition.
Correct: The anti-immigration group solicited signatures for their petition.
Suggestion: Prefixes ending with an i are always hyphenated to a root word beginning with i.
Label: Hyphenation -Attaching Prefixes to Words

Incorrect: She is suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder.
Correct: She is suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder.
Suggestion: Post is always attached to a root word without a hyphen, even when the root word begins with a t.
Label: Hyphenation -Attaching Prefixes to Words

Incorrect: They hope to reestablish contact.
Correct: They hope to reestablish contact.
Suggestion: Re is almost always attached directly to a root word without a hyphen, even when the root word begins with an e. (Rare exceptions that make distinctions between homophones include re-cover, meaning “to cover again,” to distinguish it from recover, meaning “to obtain again.”)
Label: Hyphenation -Attaching Prefixes to Words

Incorrect: The multibillion-dollar project is behind schedule.
Correct: The multibillion-dollar project is behind schedule.
Suggestion: Multi is always directly attached to a word designating an order of magnitude.
Label: Hyphenation -Attaching Prefixes to Words

Incorrect: His midcareer move was risky.
Correct: His midcareer move was risky.
Suggestion: In most words beginning with mid, the prefix is attached directly to the root word.
Label: Hyphenation -Attaching Prefixes to Words

Incorrect: Leaders should be demanding reports that provide relevant stakeholders with near real time information.
Correct: “Leaders should be demanding reports that provide relevant stakeholders with near-real-time information.”
Suggestion: The phrase “near real time” consists of three terms that combined to describe a type of information, so the phrase should be linked with hyphens

Incorrect: He found himself immersed in an in the trenches position.
Correct: “He found himself immersed in an in-the-trenches position.”
Suggestion: The position is in the trenches, so those last three words must be hyphenated when preceding the noun

Incorrect: The student had a six-month long affair with his English teacher.
Correct: “The student had a six-month-long affair with his English teacher.”
Suggestion: Here, the phrasal adjective is incompletely hyphenated, leaving the reader with the impression that a long affair was of a six-month nature. But  is part of the phrasal adjective

Incorrect: Police investigated the much talked about incident.
Correct: “Police investigated the much-talked-about incident.”
Suggestion: When  intensifies an existing phrasal adjective such as “talked about”

Incorrect: Next, the firm undergoes a revenue recognition transition process.
Correct: “Next, the firm undergoes a process of transitioning revenue recognition.” (Take care, however, that the correct meaning of the terminology is preserved in the revision.)
Suggestion: Here, the number of words in the phrasal adjective is the same as the number in each of the preceding examples, but the use of jargon makes the phrasing more dense. The sentence can be corrected to “Next, the firm undergoes a revenue-recognition-transition process,” but in this case, is better to relax the sentence by starting with the noun and progressing from there

Incorrect: It is easy to perceive a country as
Correct: The country actually exists, so it can’t be . It can, however, be “an imagined enemy.”
Suggestion: It is easy to perceive a country as

Incorrect: Children learn from experience: from what happens around them, from what they see, hear, smell, taste and touch. To absorb those experiences and make sense of the world, they need to be engaged in
Correct: The play is not .
Suggestion: Children learn from experience: from what happens around them, from what they see, hear, smell, taste and touch. To absorb those experiences and make sense of the world, they need to be engaged in

Correct: . Bear and I both took several catnaps due to the lackluster performance of both teams.
Suggestion: The

Incorrect: Smith was invited to give the presentation: “Global Development and Global Practices.”
Correct: “Smith was invited to give the presentation “Global Development and Global Practices.” (If the presentation previously was alluded to and is now being specified, set the title off from the first part of the sentence with a comma: “Smith was invited to give the presentation, “Global Development and Global Practices,” but otherwise do not replace the colon with a comma.
Suggestion: “The presentation” and the title of the presentation are appositive—one is equivalent to the other, just as in “global-development expert John Smith,” the person’s description and his name are appositive—and no intervening punctuation is necessary

Management is secure in the knowledge that it: has considered all plausible scenarios, understands the organization’s breakpoint in the event of extreme scenarios, and has effective contingency-response plans in place.
Correct: “Management is secure in the knowledge that it has considered all plausible scenarios, understands the organization’s breakpoint in the event of extreme scenarios, and has effective contingency-response plans in place.”
Suggestion: The point of the previous example is true regardless of whether a verb precedes the colon or, because each item in the in-line or vertical list begins with a verb, the colon follows a word representing another part of speech; the fact that a sentence is more extensive and complex than if it had essentially a one-item list (for example, “Management is secure in the knowledge that it has considered all plausible scenarios”) is irrelevant

Incorrect: Bad WPO ranking on most pages [are]
Correct: [in foreign investment].
Suggestion: Bad WPO ranking on most pages [are]

Incorrect: Good research
Correct: The meaning of the verb  in the idiom “to lag behind” is “to fail to keep pace with others.”
Suggestion: Good research

Incorrect: In this regard, many companies are starting with a “clean slate.”
Correct: “In this regard, many companies are starting with a clean slate.”

Incorrect: If a combination of these and other “red flags” are noted, the board should investigate them.
Correct: “If a combination of these and other red flags are noted, the board should investigate them.”
Suggestion: Brightly colored rectangles of fabric are obviously not under discussion here; the reference is clearly to abstract warning signs such as incongruous data or odd behavior

Incorrect: The board should be informed of matters related to financial reporting raised by “whistle-blowers.”
Correct: “The board should be informed of matters related to financial reporting raised by whistle-blowers.”
Suggestion: The reference to employment of a loud noise-making device is obviously an allusion to the desire of a person to get the attention of authorities and/or the media when he or she discovers institutional wrongdoing

Incorrect: Employees can be tempted to “cut corners” and act in an unethical manner.
Correct: “Employees can be tempted to cut corners and act in an unethical manner.”
Suggestion: It’s obvious that the workers under discussion face the temptation of figuratively, not literally, avoiding negotiating right angles as they navigate their way through the workday

Incorrect: “Kangaroo babies are the size of a lima bean at birth.”
Correct: “At birth, kangaroo babies are the size of a lima bean.”

Incorrect: “A famous athlete in the ancient Olympics named Milo of Kroton could break a string tied around his head with his bulging forehead veins.”
Correct: Milo of Kroton tied a string around his head with his bulging forehead veins? Why not just tie the string to, um, the string? Milo evidently wasn’t using his head after all: “In the ancient Olympics, a famous athlete named Milo of Kroton could, with his bulging forehead veins, break a string tied around his head.” (It was also unclear whether the athlete or the games were called Milo of Kroton.)
Suggestion: OK, wait, let me get this straight

Incorrect: “The first company to pioneer the idea of extended stay in 1975 was started by an apartment developer.”
Correct: “The company, which pioneered the idea of extended stay, was started by an apartment developer in 1975.” (“In 1975, an apartment developer started the company, which pioneered the idea of extended stay” is also correct and is also more active, but the context may prefer passive construction.)

Incorrect: “Mail was delivered by the Pony Express in the Wild West, a system in which riders rode to checkpoints, got a new horse, and rode on.”
Correct: The writer meant, “Mail was delivered in the Wild West by the Pony Express, a system in which riders rode to checkpoints, got a new horse, and rode on.”
Suggestion: I’ve never heard the Wild West described as a system

Incorrect: “Based on a true story, divers are left behind to float in the open seas in Open Water.”
Correct: “In , based on a true story, two divers are left behind to float in the ocean.”
Suggestion: The divers are not based on a true story; a true story inspired the movie

Incorrect: “The president says valor and sacrifice in the armed forces are no longer defined by sexual orientation at historic signing.”
Correct: Nothing. The sentence should read, “At a historic signing, the president says valor and sacrifice in the armed forces are no longer defined by sexual orientation.”
Suggestion: What does sexual orientation at a historic signing have to do with valor and sacrifice?

Incorrect: “If you learn to laugh with, and at, your family, you’ll be able to survive just about anything that life throws at you with confidence and style.”
Correct: “If you learn to laugh with (and at) your family, you’ll be able to survive, with confidence and style, just about anything that life throws at you.” (I also placed “and at” in parentheses to break up a string of commas that would, unchecked, have flattened the sentence.)
Suggestion: Why let your life throw things, much less throw things with confidence and style?

Incorrect: A  actress claims the comedian raped her in a new lawsuit.
Correct: “In a new lawsuit, a  actress,” and the predicate, “claims the comedian raped her.” (The parenthesis can also follow the verb.)
Suggestion: The sentence literally states that the rape occurred in a lawsuit. But the point is that the lawsuit states that the rape occurred, so the sentence should begin with the context

Incorrect: The attorney said that he was confident that justice would be served as he stood on the courthouse steps.
Correct: “As he stood on the courthouse steps, the attorney said that he was confident that justice would be served.” As in the previous example, the modifier can be inserted in the middle of the sentence, either before or after .
Suggestion: Just as in the first example, this sentence features a distracting misstatement. The attorney did not claim that during the time he was standing on the courthouse steps, justice would be served, but that’s what the sentence implies. To clarify that the reference to the courthouse steps is tangential to his pronouncement, it should be moved to the beginning of the sentence as a subordinate clause

Incorrect: The property belonged to Lance Benson twice, who lost the land in a divorce settlement and then bought it back in 2012.
Correct: “The property twice belonged to Lance Benson, who lost the land in a divorce settlement and then bought it back in 2012.”  could also begin the sentence, but the statement flows more smoothly when it follows the subject.
Suggestion: The antecedent, or prior reference, to  must be relocated

Incorrect: North Korea’s government says its military tested a bomb to widespread skepticism.
Correct: “To widespread skepticism, North Korea’s government says its military tested a bomb.” (Again, the modifier can be inserted before or after the verb instead.)
Suggestion: This sentence suggests that widespread skepticism was an intended result of the bomb test; it appears as if a verb such as  is missing from before “widespread skepticism.” To explicitly note that the skepticism was independent of the bomb test, the result should be introduced as a subordinate clause before the main clause

Incorrect: The rocks appeared to be the size of small cars in pictures posted by the National Park Service.

Incorrect: In a reference to the amount of medication provided to an outpatient, I read “three days’ supply for acute or chronic noncancer pain; seven days for cancer pain or palliative care.” Should  after seven also have an apostrophe?
Correct: “seven days’ supply.” I also advise replacing the semicolon with a comma and .

If this is the case, the wording should be “The poll found that 24 percent of voters said they either would abstain from voting in the general election rather than vote for Trump or Clinton or would vote for a third-party candidate.”As written, this sentence implies that not applies both to “relevant to threat identification” and to “protected by privacy laws.” However, the removal requirement applies to information that is not relevant or that is protected, so the language should emphasize this distinction

Incorrect: You will learn a new method for weight loss without neglecting your work or rearing your children.

Incorrect: This publication is neither intended to be a legal analysis nor a detailed cookbook of steps to take in every situation.
Correct: “This publication is intended to be neither a legal analysis nor a detailed cookbook of steps to take in every situation.” An alternative is to revise as follows, in which case  can come before “to be”: “This publication is not intended to be a legal analysis or a detailed cookbook of steps to take in every situation.”
Suggestion: The same idea applies to use of , which should follow, not precede, the verb “to be”

Incorrect: They may not only give insight into what to expect, but also how to handle situations that may arise.
Correct: “They may give insight not only into what to expect but also into how to handle situations that may arise.” (Note, too, that the comma between the components is extraneous.)
Suggestion: Because  should be repeated

Incorrect: You may submit a file in a different format provided that the content is the same as in the attached template.
Correct: “You may submit a file in a different format, provided that the content is the same as in the attached template.” Alternatively, the two clauses can be reversed, although in this version, the context is not as clear: “Provided that the content is the same as in the attached template, you may submit a file in a different format.”
Suggestion: Writers may be confused into thinking that in this sentence,  is a verb, but it is a conjunction (meaning “on the condition”) serving as a bridge between the main clause and the subordinate clause, and it must be preceded by a comma

Incorrect: Insurance companies and other financial services are likely to follow suit given similar pressures in their markets from new entrants.
Correct: “Insurance companies and other financial services are likely to follow suit, given similar pressures in their markets from new entrants.” However, in this case, the sentence flows better if the subordinate clause is inserted into the middle of the sentence as a parenthetical: “Insurance companies and other financial services, given similar pressures in their markets from new entrants, are likely to follow suit.”
Suggestion: Just as in the previous example, a conjunction—in this case, —is easily confused for a verb. Here, as above, it links a main clause with a subordinate clause, and a comma should precede it

Incorrect: The coach pursued a star player only to have a deal fall just short.
Correct: “The coach pursued a star player, only to have a deal fall just short.”
Suggestion: Here, the bridging word (only, here meaning “with the result that”) is an adverb rather than a conjunction, but the function is similar, and the need for a preceding comma is sustained

Incorrect: She has seen this happen before, several times in fact.
Correct: “She has seen this happen before—several times, in fact.” (Using a dash in place of what is now the first of two commas also clarifies to the reader that the dash represents a more significant transition than the weaker comma does.)
Suggestion: When a sentence takes an abrupt turn in syntactical flow, as here, the sturdy em dash (usually called simply a dash) should be called in to strengthen the transition; a comma is also required between the primary modifying phrase “several times” and “in fact,” which in turn modifies the previous phrase

Incorrect: The country has benefited from an influx of young workers—namely undocumented immigrants.
Correct: “The country has benefited from an influx of young workers—namely, undocumented immigrants.”
Suggestion: Here, a dash correctly signals an abrupt transition, but the sentence displays the common error of failing to punctuate after the adverb . (The equivalent phrases “that is to say” and “to wit” would be supplied with a comma, so for consistency, namely should also.) In this case, a comma would be correct in place of the dash, but as in the previous example, the dash sends a message that it represents the more significant of two punctuation marks

Incorrect: He’s sending a message by his actions is what he’s doing.
Correct: “He’s sending a message by his actions, is what he’s doing.” Technically, a stronger punctuation mark such as a semicolon or a dash is called for, to suggest that the second part of the sentence is a truncation of an independent clause (“that is what he is doing”), but these marks seem intrusive; a comma is a more subtle marker of a change in the sentence’s syntactical structure.
Suggestion: A grammatically flawed statement such as this should never be published unless the writer is reporting a direct quotation, and even then, the idea can be expressed in a paraphrase. Instead of “‘He’s sending a message by his actions is what he’s doing,’ said Smith,” the writer can report, “Smith said that, by his actions, Jones is sending a message.” (A careful speaker would render the sentence more print friendly by saying, “What he’s doing by his actions is sending a message,” but reporters should not correct the grammar of those they interview.)If the quotation must be published verbatim, insert a comma before “is what he’s doing” to indicate that this is a tacked-on addendum to the main clause

Incorrect: I had the same experience last year (my story differs only in the details.)
Correct: Alternatively, a complete parenthetical sentence, with the first word capitalized and a period following the last word, can follow the terminal punctuation of the previous sentence: “I had the same experience last year. (My story differs only in the details.)”
Suggestion: I had the same experience last year (my story differs only in the details).
Label: Punctuation -Parentheses

Incorrect: Steven Spielberg’s (Schindler’s List, Munich) latest film is a lighthearted one.
Correct: When parenthetically noting a person’s representative accomplishments, recast the sentence if the parenthesis follows the possessive form of the person’s name or a possessive pronoun.
Suggestion: The latest film by Steven Spielberg (Schindler’s List, Munich) is a lighthearted one.
Label: Punctuation -Parentheses

Incorrect: He pitched for the team for five seasons (1994–1998).
Correct: This sentence was originally correct.
Suggestion: He pitched for the team for five seasons (1994–1998).
Label: Punctuation -Parentheses

Incorrect: After locking the front door (Not that it mattered anymore), she hurried to the car.
Correct: Do not capitalize an incomplete sentence in parentheses.
Suggestion: After locking the front door (not that it mattered anymore), she hurried to the car.
Label: Punctuation -Parentheses

Incorrect: This manual will show you how to fix 1) widgets, 2) gadgets, and 3) gizmos.
Correct: When enumerating items in a run-in list, frame the numbers in a pair of parentheses rather than placing a closing parenthesis after the numbers.
Suggestion: This manual will show you how to fix (1) widgets, (2) gadgets, and (3) gizmos.
Label: Punctuation -Parentheses

Incorrect: The saying, “All’s well that ends well,” is the title of a Shakespeare play.
Correct: Setting an expression off from a framing sentence with commas incorrectly implies that the expression is the only one.
Suggestion: The saying “All’s well that ends well” is the title of a Shakespeare play.
Label: Punctuation -Quotations

Incorrect: He only had this to say, “I have no use for it.”
Correct: When an attribution preceding a quotation consists of a complete statement, a colon should follow the attribution.
Suggestion: He only had this to say: “I have no use for it.”
Label: Punctuation -Quotations

Incorrect: She said she meant that “The simplest solution is not always the best solution.”
Correct: Regardless of whether the original quotation consists of a full sentence, the partial paraphrase at the beginning of the sentence renders it a partial quotation, and the first letter of the first word in the original must be lowercased. (The change of case need not be indicated with brackets around the letter except in legal and similar contexts.)
Suggestion: She said she meant that “the simplest solution is not always the best solution.”
Label: Punctuation -Quotations

Incorrect: Let me put it this way: “No.”
Correct: When a quotation is preceded by a complete introductory statement or by a phrase ending in thus or “as follows,” a colon, not a comma, should separate the two elements. This sentence is correct.
Suggestion: Let me put it this way: “No.”
Label: Punctuation -Quotations

Incorrect: “Let the buyer beware,” was the lesson I learned.
Correct: When a quotation is integrated into the sentence, rather than preceding or following an attribution, no intervening punctuation is required.
Suggestion: “Let the buyer beware” was the lesson I learned.
Label: Punctuation -Quotations

Incorrect: My friend, John, is coming over today.
Correct: Setting a name off from an appositive description implies that the name identifies the only member of the description’s category — in this case, that John is the writer’s only friend (unless the writer previously referred to a friend). “My friend is coming today” fails to name John, so the name cannot be omitted and therefore should not be set off by commas.
Suggestion: My friend John is coming over today.
Label: Punctuation -Appositives

Incorrect: He was compared to WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, who has been provided asylum in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London.
Correct: Without Assange’s name, the sentence does not make sense, so it should not be set off by commas. However, in “He was compared to Julian Assange, founder of Wikileaks, who has been provided asylum in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London,” the phrase following the name is nonessential and is thus bracketed by commas.
Suggestion: He was compared to WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, who has been provided asylum in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London.
Label: Punctuation -Appositives

Incorrect: The first mate, Smith, greeted the passenger.
Correct: A vessel has only one first mate, and “The first mate greeted the passenger” is valid because Smith is inserted as a convenience to provide readers with the name but is not essential to the statement. This sentence is correct.
Suggestion: The first mate, Smith, greeted the passenger.
Label: Punctuation -Appositives

Incorrect: A contrarian by nature, Jones, raised an objection before allowing her to finish her statement.
Correct: Jones should not be set off by two commas (though the first one correctly separates the subordinate clause and the main clause), because the sentence is flawed without the name.
Suggestion: A contrarian by nature, Jones raised an objection before allowing her to finish her statement.
Label: Punctuation -Appositives

Incorrect: It’s difficult to reconcile Johnson, the philanthropist, with Johnson, the embezzler.
Correct: Here, the context makes clear that the first Johnson and the second Johnson are two sides of the same person, and philanthropist and embezzler are integral to identifying the alter egos and should not be separated from the sentence by commas.
Suggestion: It’s difficult to reconcile Johnson the philanthropist with Johnson the embezzler.
Label: Punctuation -Appositives

Incorrect: For an eighteen or nineteen-year-old, it can just seem like old guys blowing hot air.
Correct: Eighteen, a truncated form of eighteen-year-old, requires a suspensive hyphen.
Suggestion: For an eighteen- or nineteen-year-old, it can just seem like old guys blowing hot air.
Label: Punctuation -Suspensive Hyphenation

Incorrect: Cinder cones are formed by short eruptions of pea-to-walnut-sized lava rocks injected with gas and air.
Correct: The full form of the construction is “pea-sized to walnut-sized lava rocks,” so pea, though sized is correctly omitted, should not be hyphenated to to, and to should not be hyphenated to walnut.
Suggestion: Cinder cones are formed by short eruptions of pea- to walnut-sized lava rocks injected with gas and air.
Label: Punctuation -Suspensive Hyphenation

Incorrect: The medication alleviates flu or cold-related symptoms.
Correct: The medication alleviates flu-related symptoms, not flu, so flu needs a suspensive hyphen.
Suggestion: The medication alleviates flu- or cold-related symptoms.
Label: Punctuation -Suspensive Hyphenation

Incorrect: The best-seller follows the action and comedy-packed story of a fairy turned human boy.
Correct: The story is packed with action and packed with comedy, so action requires a suspensive hyphen.
Suggestion: The best-seller follows the action- and comedy-packed story of a fairy turned human boy.
Label: Punctuation -Suspensive Hyphenation

Incorrect: Here’s what you need to pack up for a three or four day holiday weekend.
Correct: The reference is to a holiday weekend lasting three or four days, so three and four require hyphens connecting them, respectively, to an implied and an actual instance of day.
Suggestion: Here’s what you need to pack up for a three- or four-day holiday weekend.
Label: Punctuation -Suspensive Hyphenation

Incorrect: We did not want one of our own, a minority no less, to feel offended.
Correct: “No less” must be set off from “a minority.” A comma will suffice, but then the four words must also be set off from the base sentence with stronger punctuation — a pair of em dashes.
Suggestion: We did not want one of our own — a minority, no less — to feel offended.
Label: Punctuation -Punctuation Within Parenthesis

Incorrect: The data showed that we were not on track to achieve our goal, nowhere near actually.
Correct: Actually does not refer to a place that the progress was in proximity to; it’s a tag to be attached to “nowhere near,” which, representing a break in thought, should be set off by an em dash.
Suggestion: The data showed that we were not on track to achieve our goal — nowhere near, actually.
Label: Punctuation -Punctuation Within Parenthesis

Incorrect: The most thought-provoking delicacy was, let’s have a drum roll please, Rocky Mountain oysters.
Correct: Please is a tag attached to the phrase “let’s have a drum roll,” so it should be set off from the phrase with a comma; the phrase and the attachment should in turn be distinct from the base sentence.
Suggestion: The most thought-provoking delicacy was — let’s have a drum roll, please — Rocky Mountain oysters.
Label: Punctuation -Punctuation Within Parenthesis

Incorrect: Not in years, like more than ten years, have I seen someone so committed to owning the stage.
Correct: Like, in this usage, is related to “for example” and should be set off from the following phrase, which, with the tag, constitutes an interjection.
Suggestion: Not in years — like, more than ten years — have I seen someone so committed to owning the stage.
Label: Punctuation -Punctuation Within Parenthesis

Incorrect: Such pioneers trigger and indeed hope for gentrification — leading to more and more middle-class home buyers being willing to take a chance on the neighborhood.
Correct: Indeed is an interjection within an interjection and must be framed by commas, and the larger interjection should be set off from the rest of the sentence. The part of the sentence after gentrification, however, is not a sudden break of thought, and therefore an em dash separating the two clauses is not required.
Suggestion: Such pioneers trigger — and, indeed, hope for — gentrification, leading to more and more middle-class home buyers being willing to take a chance on the neighborhood.
Label: Punctuation -Punctuation Within Parenthesis

Incorrect: An heirloom plant may have been grown in the same location for say a hundred years.
Correct: Say, interjected into this sentence, must be bracketed by commas.
Suggestion: An heirloom plant may have been grown in the same location for, say, a hundred years.
Label: Punctuation -Parenthetical Interjections

Incorrect: It’s within this context then that we must consider the arrival of the military advisers.
Correct: The transitional word then should be framed by commas.
Suggestion: It’s within this context, then, that we must consider the arrival of the military advisers.
Label: Punctuation -Parenthetical Interjections

Incorrect: Seemingly minor points could hamper the platform’s popularity, and, hence game sales.
Correct: Hence is the interjected word in this example; the only punctuation required is that which sets it off.
Suggestion: Seemingly minor points could hamper the platform’s popularity and, hence, game sales.
Label: Punctuation -Parenthetical Interjections

Incorrect: Keep solving for “x” and “y” with different numbers, until finally, you try 70.
Correct: There’s no need for a comma preceding until, but one should follow it to match the comma following the interjection finally.
Suggestion: Keep solving for “x” and “y” with different numbers until, finally, you try 70.
Label: Punctuation -Parenthetical Interjections

Incorrect: That process might even involve such old-fashioned ideas as, gasp!, putting search results in alphabetical or chronological order when requested.
Correct: A dramatic interjection such as gasp! merits stronger signals of interruption.
Suggestion: That process might even involve such old-fashioned ideas as — gasp! — putting search results in alphabetical or chronological order when requested.
Label: Punctuation -Parenthetical Interjections

Incorrect: One of the team’s all-time greats, John Smith took over after Robert Jones was injured.
Correct: The original sentence is correct only if Smith was mentioned by name in a previous sentence, in which case only his last name would be used. Otherwise, bracket his name, used appositively in relation to the first clause, with a pair of commas.
Suggestion: One of the team’s all-time greats, John Smith, took over after Robert Jones was injured.
Label: Punctuation -Parenthetical Words and Phrases

Incorrect: There were a bunch of policies, local ones mostly, that I found well intentioned but ineffective.
Correct: The tag mostly must be set off from the rest of the interjection by a comma (unless it precedes “local ones”). So that the parenthetical stands out more distinctly, it should be set off from the rest of the sentence by an em dash to distinguish the break in thought from the separation of the adverbial tag.
Suggestion: There were a bunch of policies — local ones, mostly — that I found well intentioned but ineffective.Alterna.: There were a bunch of policies — mostly local ones — that I found well intentioned but ineffective.
Label: Punctuation -Parenthetical Words and Phrases

Incorrect: The dust covers allowed the grease to leak out, and worse, allowed dirt and water to get in.
Correct: Worse is the parenthetical, so it alone should be set off by commas.
Suggestion: The dust covers allowed the grease to leak out and, worse, allowed dirt and water to get in.
Label: Punctuation -Parenthetical Words and Phrases

Incorrect: He was extremely interested in the job when Thomas was hired, and by many accounts, was the second choice.
Correct: “By many accounts” is parenthetical and is the only element of the sentence to require internal punctuation.
Suggestion: He was extremely interested in the job when Thomas was hired and, by many accounts, was the second choice.
Label: Punctuation -Parenthetical Words and Phrases

Incorrect: Older students model good behavior, and through continual peer mentoring, develop their teaching skills and solidify their own knowledge.
Correct: As with the two previous examples, no comma is required before the and separating the two clauses. (A comma is necessary only if a noun or pronoun follows the conjunction; the comma then distinguishes one independent clause from another.)
Suggestion: Older students model good behavior and, through continual peer mentoring, develop their teaching skills and solidify their own knowledge.
Label: Punctuation -Parenthetical Words and Phrases

Incorrect: This garment is made of high quality material.
Correct: This garment is made of high-quality material.
Suggestion: High and quality combine to describe the material, so they should be hyphenated.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: The family owned the first self service laundry in the state.
Correct: The family owned the first self-service laundry in the state.
Suggestion: Phrasal adjectives in which the first word is self are nearly always hyphenated, as are compound nouns beginning with self, such as self-reflection.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: She was delighted to see that the patent leather shoes were still on sale.
Correct: She was delighted to see that the patent leather shoes were still on sale.
Suggestion: Some set phrases, such as “patent leather,” are unambiguous because of familiarity and need not be hyphenated; these open compounds are listed in dictionaries.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: He didn’t want to be a type-cast actor.
Correct: He didn’t want to be a typecast actor.
Suggestion: Typecast is one of many compound adjectives that are closed; such permanent compounds appear in dictionaries as such.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: Jones was a one of a kind performer.
Correct: Jones was a one-of-a-kind performer.
Suggestion: The words in the phrase “one of a kind” should be linked with hyphens to indicate that they combine to describe the kind of performer Jones was.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: Her reply was as follows “We have no comment in response to the allegations.”
Correct: When the attribution is a complete phrase that sets up the following quotation, use a colon.
Suggestion: Her reply was as follows: “We have no comment in response to the allegations.”
Label: Punctuation -Attribution

Incorrect: She said that the management “has no comment in response to the allegations.”
Correct: When an attribution is followed by a paraphrase that is grammatically integrated with a partial quotation so that the paraphrase and the partial quotation form a complete sentence, no punctuation should appear between the paraphrase and the partial quotation. This sentence is correct.
Suggestion: She said that the management “has no comment in response to the allegations.”
Label: Punctuation -Attribution

Incorrect: She said “We have no comment in response to the allegations.”
Correct: Follow a simple attribution preceding a quotation with a comma.
Suggestion: She said, “We have no comment in response to the allegations.”
Label: Punctuation -Attribution

Incorrect: “We have no comment in response to the allegations” she said.
Correct: Follow a quotation preceding an attribution with a comma (unless the sentence is interrogative or imperative, in which case a question mark or an exclamation point should replace the comma).
Suggestion: “We have no comment in response to the allegations,” she said.
Label: Punctuation -Attribution

Incorrect: In response to the allegations she said that the management has no comment.
Correct: When a quotation is paraphrased and an attribution separates two parts of the paraphrase, precede the attribution with a comma.
Suggestion: In response to the allegations, she said that the management has no comment.
Label: Punctuation -Attribution

Incorrect: Read these tips for space and time-efficient gardening.
Correct: The tips pertain to gardening that is efficient in both space and time, so space should be hyphenated to indicate that the instance of efficient that would normally follow it has been elided.
Suggestion: Read these tips for space- and time-efficient gardening.
Label: Punctuation -Suspensive Hyphenation

Incorrect: The issue touches on the tension between middle- and upper-class values.
Correct: Elision of the first use of class is correct.
Suggestion: The issue touches on the tension between middle- and upper-class values.
Label: Punctuation -Suspensive Hyphenation

Incorrect: You’re either over- or underwhelmed.
Correct: When two words have the same root, spell both words out. (Some guides allow such constructions, such as shown in “He’s scheduled both pre- and postgame briefings,” but it’s best to spell out both words in such a phrase.)
Suggestion: You’re either overwhelmed or underwhelmed.
Label: Punctuation -Suspensive Hyphenation

Incorrect: This ferry is for Norway-and-Sweden-bound passengers.
Correct: Even if the statement refers to people bound for both Norway and Sweden, rather than one or the other, those passengers cannot visit both countries simultaneously, so they, along with those bound for one country or the other, are referenced in this revision. (“This ferry is for Norway- or Sweden-bound passengers” implies that the destination could be either Norway or Sweden, a statement that would mean the precise destination is unknown.)
Suggestion: This ferry is for Norway- and Sweden-bound passengers.
Label: Punctuation -Suspensive Hyphenation

Incorrect: The marketing campaign targets the 18-to-34-year-old demographic.
Correct: The basic rule applies for number ranges. (However, the sentence could be revised to “The marketing campaign targets 18- to 34-year-olds” or “The marketing campaign targets people ages 18–34.”)
Suggestion: The marketing campaign targets the 18- to 34-year-old demographic.
Label: Punctuation -Suspensive Hyphenation

Incorrect: Am I to blame? he asked himself.
Correct: A question mark may appear in the midst of a sentence if a direct question is part of that sentence. This sentence is correct.
Suggestion: Am I to blame? he asked himself.
Label: Punctuation -Question Marks

Incorrect: “Were you in the war?,” I asked.
Correct: When a question mark appears at the end of a quotation or a line of dialogue, it supplants the comma that would normally be located there. (An exception is made for the previous rule when what is quoted is a title of a work, as in “His short story ‘Who Will Watch the Watchers?,’ his first published piece, appeared in an anthology.”)
Suggestion: “Were you in the war?” I asked.
Label: Punctuation -Question Marks

Incorrect: I wondered whether she would ever speak to me again?
Correct: No question mark is used in an indirect quotation. (The same rule applies when a question within a sentence consists of a single word that often begins a stated question, such as in “I knew it would happen, but I asked myself when.”)
Suggestion: I wondered whether she would ever speak to me again.
Label: Punctuation -Question Marks

Incorrect: Would you please hand me that report?
Correct: A request that could be truncated into an imperative does not require a question mark.
Suggestion: Would you please hand me that report.
Label: Punctuation -Question Marks

Incorrect: Why, when she’s already upset, would you say, “I told you so?”
Correct: A question mark appears after a close quotation mark, not before it, if it applies to the framing sentence rather than the quoted material.
Suggestion: Why, when she’s already upset, would you say, “I told you so”?
Label: Punctuation -Question Marks

Incorrect: He’s a sharp dressed young man.
Correct: Together, sharp and dressed describe the young man, so they should be hyphenated.
Suggestion: He’s a sharp-dressed young man.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: As usual, the event was well-attended.
Correct: Most phrasal adjectives are hyphenated before the noun they modify but open when they follow the noun.
Suggestion: As usual, the event was well attended.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: I sympathize with his long-suffering wife.
Correct: This example is correct; without the hyphen, it refers to a suffering wife who is long.
Suggestion: I sympathize with his long-suffering wife.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: She was touched by the open-hearted gesture.
Correct: Some phrasal adjectives have, because of familiarity, become closed compounds; hardworking is one of them. (However, in this case, note that the similar phrasal adjective in “open-heart surgery” is hyphenated.)
Suggestion: She was touched by the openhearted gesture.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: The injury turned out to have been self inflicted.
Correct: Phrasal adjectives beginning with self are exceptions to the open-after-a-noun rule; they should always be hyphenated, even after the noun.
Suggestion: The injury turned out to have been self-inflicted.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: The three types of rock are: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic.
Correct: A colon is redundant to a verb and should never follow one.
Suggestion: The three types of rock are igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic.
Label: Punctuation -Colons

Incorrect: That’s the key: What to do about rust.
Correct: Do not capitalize the first word of a phrase or an incomplete sentence that follows a colon unless it is a proper noun. (Some style guides recommend capitalizing the first word following a colon only when the explanatory content consists of two or more sentences. However, others consider that suggestion too restrictive and advise capitalizing one or more complete explanatory sentences; I endorse this style.)
Suggestion: That’s the key: what to do about rust.
Label: Punctuation -Colons

Incorrect: Try the following steps: Rinse, lather, and repeat.
Correct: The imperative statement following the colon is a complete thought; this sentence is correct.
Suggestion: Try the following steps: Rinse, lather, and repeat.
Label: Punctuation -Colons

Incorrect: Smith said: “That’s the way I look at it.”
Correct: An attribution should be followed by a comma, not a colon. (Exception: Use a colon if the attribution is a complete thought, as in “Smith summed up his viewpoint tersely: “That’s the way I look at it.”)
Suggestion: Smith said, “That’s the way I look at it.”
Label: Punctuation -Colons

Incorrect: For example: Compare the two images below.
Correct: Always use a comma, not a colon, after an introductory phrase.
Suggestion: For example, compare the two images below.
Label: Punctuation -Colons

Incorrect: His comment left me wondering whether I’d be “invited to resign”, as he had put it.
Correct: A comma never follows a quotation mark.
Suggestion: His comment left me wondering whether I’d be “invited to resign,” as he had put it.
Label: Punctuation -Partial Quotations

Incorrect: Although Smith agreed with the assessment, he added, “We resent the tone.”
Correct: A subordinate clause has been attached to this attribution and quotation, but the statement remains a complete thought. This is not a partial quotation, so the sentence is correct.
Suggestion: Although Smith agreed with the assessment, he added, “We resent the tone.”
Label: Punctuation -Partial Quotations

Incorrect: It’s difficult to say it will work, Jones agreed, “But I haven’t heard any better ideas.”
Correct: In this case, in contrast to the previous example, the quoted material, though it might have been uttered as a complete thought, has been attached to a paraphrase, rendering it a partial quotation.
Suggestion: It’s difficult to say it will work, Jones agreed, “but I haven’t heard any better ideas.”
Label: Punctuation -Partial Quotations

Incorrect: Jane said that she would prefer to do some “light reading.”
Correct: Jane may have used the words “light reading” in her comment, but it’s not necessary, when paraphrasing, to retain quotation marks around a fragment of the comment actually uttered or written unless the wording is notable.
Suggestion: Jane said that she would prefer to do some light reading.
Label: Punctuation -Partial Quotations

Incorrect: “Never have I seen a better display,” was his welcome comment.
Correct: There’s no reason to insert a comma between the quote and this style of attribution, because the quote constitutes the subject, followed by the verb and the rest of the predicate.
Suggestion: “Never have I seen a better display” was his welcome comment.
Label: Punctuation -Partial Quotations

Incorrect: It was in my post office box.
Correct: “Post office” is one of many permanent compounds — noun phrases so well established that confusion is considered unlikely and that are therefore not hyphenated when they combine to modify a following noun. (Permanent compounds are listed in dictionaries.) This sentence is correct.
Suggestion: It was in my post office box.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: The project finances construction of energy efficient homes.
Correct: This sentence refers to homes that are energy efficient, not efficient homes that are energy.
Suggestion: The project finances construction of energy-efficient homes.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: The figures above reflect cost of living adjustments.
Correct: Here, the sentence does not pertain to living adjustments and their cost; the phrase “cost of living” modifies adjustments.
Suggestion: The figures above reflect cost-of-living adjustments.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: She is still developing her expository writing skills.
Correct: Skills in expository writing, rather than writing skills that are expository, are the topic of this sentence.
Suggestion: She is still developing her expository-writing skills.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: Images must have high quality resolution.
Correct: This sentence concerns resolution of high quality, not quality resolution that is high.
Suggestion: Images must have high-quality resolution.
Label: Punctuation -Phrasal Adjectives

Incorrect: We just need to meet this recall movement head on; turn a bad thing into a good thing; and move toward reforming the city for everybody.
Correct: Semicolons are not appropriate for separating simple list items, even if they’re long phrases.
Suggestion: We just need to meet this recall movement head on, turn a bad thing into a good thing, and move toward reforming the city for everybody.
Label: Punctuation -Strong-Comma Semicolons

Incorrect: The possible color combinations are green, blue, and red; green, blue, and yellow; green, red, and yellow; blue, red, and yellow.
Correct: When the final semicolon in a complex series of items replaces a serial comma, it should be followed by a conjunction, just as a serial comma should.
Suggestion: The possible color combinations are green, blue, and red; green, blue, and yellow; green, red, and yellow; and blue, red, and yellow.
Label: Punctuation -Strong-Comma Semicolons

Incorrect: The band was playing when gusting winds blew the helicopter carrying him; his girlfriend, Jane Smith; and his pilot, John Doe, into an electrical tower.
Correct: A phrase that applies to items separated by semicolons should not end the sentence, as it will appear to apply only to the final item; instead, recast the sentence.
Suggestion: The band was playing when gusting winds blew the helicopter carrying him, as well as his girlfriend, Jane Smith, and his pilot, John Doe, into an electrical tower.
Label: Punctuation -Strong-Comma Semicolons

Incorrect: The three cities I’ve live in are Boston, Baltimore, and Albany, New York.
Correct: A semicolon is not necessary when only one list item includes a comma and that item is located at or can be moved to the end of the sentence. This sentence is correct. (However, note this version: “The three cities I’ve live in, in chronological order, are Albany, New York; Boston; and Baltimore.” The state in which a major city is located usually does not need to be identified, and the state name is generally not included for consistent treatment.)
Suggestion: The three cities I’ve live in are Boston, Baltimore, and Albany, New York.
Label: Punctuation -Strong-Comma Semicolons

Incorrect: For my imaginary dinner guests, I chose John Doe, a nineteenth-century philosopher, Jane Roe, one of the first female mathematicians, and James Smith, an early paleontologist.
Correct: Although this sentence organizes names and descriptions in a straightforward manner, it’s best to observe the basic rule and use a semicolon after the first two descriptions. (However, constructions such as the following are clear without using semicolons to separate the choices: “If you think it’s true, write T, if you think it’s false, write F, and if you’re not sure, write X.”)
Suggestion: For my imaginary dinner guests, I chose John Doe, a nineteenth-century philosopher; Jane Roe, one of the first female mathematicians; and James Smith, an early paleontologist.
Label: Punctuation -Strong-Comma Semicolons

Incorrect: But I thought…
Correct: Although word-processing programs enable writers to form a single-character ellipsis by typing three periods in a row, proper style for an ellipsis is as described above. If the intent is to indicate faltering speech, use three dots without terminal punctuation, but if the sentence is deliberately left incomplete (for example, in the statement “The speech begins, ‘Friends, Romans, countrymen . . . .’”), add terminal punctuation, as shown in the example in parentheses here.
Suggestion: But I thought . . .
Label: Punctuation -Ellipsis

Incorrect: The directions . . . are unnecessarily complicated.
Correct: If an ellipsis is used to show omission of one or more words in the middle of a sentence, use three dots. This sentence is correct.
Suggestion: The directions . . . are unnecessarily complicated.
Label: Punctuation -Ellipsis

Incorrect: I applied . . . but was not hired . . . for a job with the company.
Correct: Em dashes, not ellipses, should be used to indicate a sudden break in thought.
Suggestion: I applied — but was not hired — for a job with the company.
Label: Punctuation -Ellipsis

Incorrect: Don’t touch that button marked Self-Destruct, or….
Correct: Interruption of a remark should be signaled by an em dash, not an ellipsis.
Suggestion: Don’t touch that button marked Self-Destruct, or —
Label: Punctuation -Ellipsis

Incorrect: Consider the rhythm in the phrase “. . . our fathers brought forth a new nation. . .”
Correct: Don’t use ellipses before or after an incomplete quotation to indicate deliberately elided text.
Suggestion: Consider the rhythm in the phrase “our fathers brought forth a new nation.”
Label: Punctuation -Ellipsis

I think that not all of these words are always treated the same. Take your example, “…therefore, she decided to take a course in colloquial Greek.”  If any of your revisions were to reverse the words to read “…she therefore decided to take a course…”, do you need commas to set off the word “therefore”?  In my job, people do this all the time, as in “She, therefore, decided to take a course…”  I am constantly removing what I believe are clutter commas. However, taking your list of words (however, moreover, therefore, thus, consequently, furthermore, unfortunately), some seem to require being set off by commas. For example, “John decided to take a course in Italian; she, however, decided to take a course in Greek.” I feel that “moreover” and “unfortunately” probably need to be set off by commas in cases like this, whereas “thus,” “consequently,” plus/minus “furthermore” do not.
Suggestion: Giving children the opportunity to make decisions is necessary for independent development; however, without clear, consistent boundaries, their sense of comfort and security can be diminished.
