Incorrect: In the future, Smith says she looks forward to having her team work more with data analytics.
Correct: “In the future, Smith says, she looks forward to having her team work more with data analytics.”
Suggestion: Without a comma after says to correspond to the one following , this sentence appears to awkwardly state that it is known in the present that in the future Smith will say that she looks forward to having her team work with more data analytics. But “Smith says” is an attribution, so the phrase should be bracketed by a pair of commas

Incorrect: As rooftop solar panels become more common, company executives say they need new products that will distinguish the business from its many competitors.
Correct: “As rooftop solar panels become more common, company executives say, they need new products that will distinguish the business from its many competitors.”
Suggestion: The error in this sentence is not as obvious as the one in the previous example. However, the implication here is that the company executives are making a statement at the same time as rooftop solar panels become more common. This may be technically accurate, but it’s not the point of the sentence. “Company executives say” interrupts the sentence to identify the source of the statement

Incorrect: There are about 365.25 days in a year according to NASA.
Correct: “There are about 365.25 days in a year, according to NASA.”
Suggestion: Because of the lack of internal punctuation in this sentence, it appears to quantify the number of days in a specific typed of year—one that is according to NASA. An attribution, regardless of whether it precedes, interrupts, or follows a statement, should be set off from that statement. If the attribution appears at the head or tail of the sentence, however, only one comma is necessary to set it off from the main clause

Incorrect: That’s why they choose to live in San Francisco proper instead of say a suburb like Daly City.
Correct: “That’s why they choose to live in San Francisco proper instead of, say, a suburb like Daly City.”
Suggestion: In this sentence,  is being used as a synonym for the parenthetical phrase “for example,” and like that phrase, it must be set off from the sentence

Incorrect: As these companies continue to evolve, a focus on organizational structure and governance framework as well as monitoring, testing, and reporting, become increasingly important.
Correct: a subordinate clause, a main clause, and a parenthetical clause within the main clause. However, the parenthetical clause is not correctly set off from the main clause—a comma must precede “as well as” (the beginning of the parenthetical phrase) to counterbalance the one that follows  (the end of the parenthetical phrase): “As these companies continue to evolve, a focus on organizational structure and governance framework, as well as monitoring, testing, and reporting, become increasingly important.”
Suggestion: This sentence consists of three components

Incorrect: It’s imperative for them to have a longer-term approach to the market, and based on that, make permanent changes to their operations.
Correct: “It’s imperative for them to have a longer-term approach to the market and, based on that, make permanent changes to their operations.”
Suggestion: The superfluous first comma in this sentence exists on the mistaken presumption that it must be placed there to separate two independent clauses. However, this sentence consists of a single main clause with the parenthetical phrase “based on that,” which should be preceded and followed by a pair of commas, so the first comma must follow, not precede,

Incorrect: The graffiti included the words: “Black lives matter.”
Correct: “The graffiti included the words ‘Black lives matter.’” (There is an unlikely exception: The words have been previously alluded to, and now they are being explicitly stated. In that case, the colon is appropriate.)
Suggestion: This simple declarative statement requires no punctuation between the descriptive opening phrase and the quotation

Incorrect: Smith planned to head to the region immediately and promised people in the area: “No individual, no family, no community will be left behind.”
Correct: “Smith planned to head to the region later Wednesday and promised people in the area, ‘No individual, no family, no community will be left behind.’” (If the attribution constitutes a complete thought, a colon is correct, as in this revision: “Smith planned to head to the region later Wednesday, and his promise to the people in the area was emphatic: ‘No individual, no family, no community will be left behind.’”)
Suggestion: In journalism, a colon is often used to signal that a quotation is about to follow an attribution, but a comma is much more appropriate, because whereas colons generally punctuate with the halting force of a period, a comma is more smoothly transitional

Incorrect: The question is: “How did the outcome of World War I contribute to the advent of World War II?”
Correct: “The question is, ‘How did the outcome of World War I contribute to the advent of World War II?’” (If the question is merely posed in a narrative, rather than a reproduction of a written question, the quotation marks—and the capitalization of the first word—aren’t necessary: “The question is, how did the outcome of World War I contribute to the advent of World War II?”
Suggestion: This sentence presumably refers to a written question on an examination of some kind, as in a high school history test, but whether it is a quotation or simply part of a narrative, a colon is obstructive (as explained in the previous item), and, just as a comma generally follows an attribution (such as “she said”) that introduces a quotation—again, see above—a comma is appropriate to separate the setup phrase here and the quotation

Incorrect: Without federal instructions, he added, “People are just going to keep putting stuff out on the road with no guidance on how do we do this the right way.”
Correct: “Without federal instructions, he added, ‘people are just going to keep putting stuff out on the road with no guidance on how do we do this the right way.’” (As originally written, the implication is that the person added the comment despite having no federal instructions.)
Suggestion: The quotation marks accurately denote the speaker’s exact statement, but the writer has inserted a modifying phrase to provide additional context, paraphrasing the speaker’s intent. Because the combination of this phrase and the original statement constitute a grammatically complete sentence, the first word of the original quotation should be lowercased to indicate that it has been incorporated into a more comprehensive statement

Incorrect: “You can admit that ‘Yes, there is a need in a humane society for institutions that take care of people who are poor.’”
Correct: “You can admit that, ‘yes, there is a need in a humane society for institutions that take care of people who are poor.’”
Suggestion: As with the previous example, the initial paraphrase has been inserted to provide context, so  is an interjection, so it must be preceded and followed by punctuation

Incorrect: The lawsuit also alleges that Remington and the other defendants “Marketed and promoted the assaultive qualities and military uses of AR-15s to civilian purchasers.”
Correct: “The lawsuit also alleges that Remington and the other defendants ‘marketed and promoted the assaultive qualities and military uses of AR-15s to civilian purchasers.’”
Suggestion: Here, the quoted material was never stated or written as a complete sentence. As a partial quotation, it should begin with a word that starts with a lowercase letter

Incorrect: In circumstances, such as these, are our strengths and weaknesses revealed.
Correct: “In circumstances such as these are our strengths and weaknesses revealed.”
Suggestion: A pair of commas around “such as these” presumes that the phrase is optional, but “In circumstances are our strengths and weaknesses revealed,” though a valid statement, misses the point of the sentence, which is intended to relate the sentiment to a particular set of circumstances, so the phrase is essential and should not be set off

Incorrect: The use of the technology allows companies, such as World Wide Wickets, to transfer funds faster, cheaper, and in a trackable mechanism.
Correct: “The use of the technology allows companies such as World Wide Wickets to transfer funds faster, cheaper, and in a trackable mechanism.”
Suggestion: Out of context, it may not be clear whether the parenthesis is necessary, but when one accepts the assumption that the company has already been mentioned, the phrase seems oddly intrusive when treated as an interjection, while its integral placement in the statement is natural

Incorrect: Specific employee information, such as Social Security numbers and I-9 forms for employment eligibility must be transferred in accordance with law.
Correct: “Specific employee information, such as Social Security numbers and I-9 forms for employment eligibility, must be transferred in accordance with law.” (The sentence is also correct without internal punctuation.)
Suggestion: The examples given in this sentence are helpful but not essential, so the phrase beginning with “such as” and ending before the verb phrase “must be transferred” should be treated parenthetically. This sentence starts off correctly but neglects to close off the parenthesis with a second comma

Incorrect: Men’s health industry
Correct: Economic Opportunities
Suggestion: Men’s health industry

Incorrect: The commission uncovered an industry
Correct: opportunity.
Suggestion: The commission uncovered an industry

Incorrect: A reader responding to an editorial opposing a proposed state requirement for schools to provide compulsory instruction in cursive handwriting: 2. A reader urging the newspaper staff to scrutinize elected officials in order to make their failings public:
Correct: Some English speakers prefer .
Suggestion: First, I want to assure you I believe in Note

Incorrect: A reader talking about the way politicians try to hurry the public into making decisions before all the facts are known:
Correct: to perceive to be the same as something or someone previously known or encountered.
Suggestion: There are plenty that oppose this, but most intelligent people

Incorrect: He was still far back in third place in most polls.
Correct: “Wind-energy, solar-energy, hydrothermal-energy, and geothermal-energy sources are constituting larger portions of the overall energy pool.” Alternatively, suspensive hyphenation—“Wind-, solar-, hydrothermal-, and geothermal-energy sources are constituting larger portions of the overall energy pool”—could be employed, though it looks awkward when used for more than a couple of terms.
Suggestion: “Third place” is a simple noun phrase that requires no hyphenation. If it were to be a phrasal adjective modifying another word, a hyphen would be called for, as in the sentence “She had to be content with a third-place finish in her best race.”

Incorrect: I got my cat spaded and she got [a] hernia from the stitches.
Correct: I am contemplating spaying and declawing my kitten when she turns 6 months old.
Suggestion: I got my cat spayed and she got [a] hernia from the stitches.

Incorrect: I’ll expect you on the 25th, then.
Correct: When a date is mentioned in isolation, spell it out as an ordinal.
Suggestion: I’ll expect you on the twenty-fifth, then.
Label: Style -Months, Days, and Years in Dates

Incorrect: The study was concluded on 8/22/13.
Correct: Few countries observe the US month/date/year system, so foreign readers may misunderstand the date, and the numerical style is inappropriate for formal content. (If an abbreviated style is necessary, as in a table, style dates, for example, “22 Aug 2013,” or use “8/22/13” if required but specify the system in a note.)
Suggestion: The study was concluded on August 22, 2012.
Label: Style -Months, Days, and Years in Dates

Incorrect: Registration will close on March 31st, 2013.
Correct: Omit ordinals (st, nd, rd, and th) in dates.
Suggestion: Registration will close on March 31, 2013.
Label: Style -Months, Days, and Years in Dates

Incorrect: On November 5, 2012, the store shut its doors for the last time.
Correct: This style for month, date, and year is formatted correctly.
Suggestion: On November 5, 2012, the store shut its doors for the last time.
Label: Style -Months, Days, and Years in Dates

Incorrect: The next occurrence was in February, 1978.
Correct: Do not insert a comma between the month and the year when no date is given.
Suggestion: The next occurrence was in February 1978.
Label: Style -Months, Days, and Years in Dates

Incorrect: It was common knowledge that things fall down when you drop them.
Correct: It was common knowledge that things fall down when you drop them.
Suggestion: “Things fall down when you drop them” is a perpetual truth, so the verbs in the statement should be in the present tense regardless of the tense of the sentence’s initial verb.
Label: Style -Tense Shifts

Incorrect: He posited that the universe consisted of a space-time continuum.
Correct: He posited that the universe consists of a space-time continuum.
Suggestion: If the proposition is true, the universe is still composed as stated.
Label: Style -Tense Shifts

Incorrect: She told me that the ACLU was a Communist organization.
Correct: She told me that the ACLU is a Communist organization.
Suggestion: Depending on the context, was may be correct — the person who made the statement may have been referring to a previous state — but if she was referring to it in its present state, the present tense should be used to refer to that state regardless of the use of past tense to report the statement.
Label: Style -Tense Shifts

Incorrect: The instructors came up with this engaging lesson because they want to give younger students a base of understanding for future science projects.
Correct: The instructors came up with this engaging lesson because they want to give younger students a base of understanding for future science projects.
Suggestion: The goal of the instructors is presumably perpetual and has no relation to the verb used to explain what the instructors did. However, in a historical context describing what former instructors did, wanted is correct.
Label: Style -Tense Shifts

Incorrect: He faced a steep learning curve in terms of just how serious fans are about the football program.
Correct: He faced a steep learning curve in terms of just how serious fans are about the football program.
Suggestion: Assuming that passion of the fans has not diminished, they should be described as still being serious about the football program.
Label: Style -Tense Shifts

Incorrect: He coined the term “the Silk Road,” a network of Eurasian roads and trade routes.
Correct: The term “the Silk Road” is a not a network of Eurasian roads and trade routes; it is the name for such a network.
Suggestion: He coined the term “the Silk Road” to refer to a network of Eurasian roads and trade routes.
Label: Style -Confusion of a Thing and Its Name

Incorrect: Polygyny translates to “having many wives.”
Correct: The word polygyny is used to describe a concept. However, the concept is not translated to “having many wives”; the word for it is so translated. (The correction encloses the word in quotation marks because the tool for constructing these exercises does not allow italics for the sample sentences; the word should be italicized rather than set in quotation marks.)
Suggestion: “Polygyny” translates to “having many wives.”
Label: Style -Confusion of a Thing and Its Name

Incorrect: We were introduced to the precocious child Prof, short for “Professor.”
Correct: The child is not an abbreviation of Professor; his or her name is. Here, too, Professor should be italicized rather than framed in quotation marks.
Suggestion: We were introduced to the precocious child Prof, whose nickname is short for “Professor.”
Label: Style -Confusion of a Thing and Its Name

Incorrect: Karaoke, which means “empty orchestra,” is singing along to a recording of a song in which the original vocals have been deleted.
Correct: The name for karaoke, not the activity itself, means “empty orchestra.”
Suggestion: Karaoke (the name means “empty orchestra”) is singing along to a recording of a song in which the original vocals have been deleted.Alterna.: Karaoke — the word is Japanese for “empty orchestra” — is singing along to a recording of a song in which the original vocals have been deleted.
Label: Style -Confusion of a Thing and Its Name

Incorrect: A resume, or a CV (which means “curriculum vitae”), basically a more detailed resume, is the most important document in your job search.
Correct: The initials for the document, not the document itself, represent the term “curriculum vitae.”
Suggestion: A resume, or a CV (the initials stand for “curriculum vitae”), basically a more detailed resume, is the most important document in your job search.
Label: Style -Confusion of a Thing and Its Name

Incorrect: This city of 3,000,000 has come a long way since its humble beginnings.
Correct: For improved readability, spell out large round numbers.
Suggestion: This city of three million has come a long way since its humble beginnings.
Label: Style -Large Numbers

Incorrect: The database amounts to about fifty million documents and about 150 billion words.
Correct: When using a term of magnitude (million, billion, and so on), apply the basic rule for spelling out numbers or using numerals: Use a numeral for a number exceeding one hundred and spell out numbers of less than one hundred. When two or more numbers that refer to the same thing are mixed (at least one over and one under one hundred), use numerals consistently. This sentence is correct. (Documents and words are related but not identical.)
Suggestion: The database amounts to about fifty million documents and about 150 billion words.
Label: Style -Large Numbers

Incorrect: The following year, about 2,389,000 units were produced.
Correct: For improved readability, very large numbers should be rounded up and reduced to a decimal fraction to one or two digits.
Suggestion: The following year, about 2.4 million units were produced.
Label: Style -Large Numbers

Incorrect: The city’s population is about 2,245,389.
Correct: Do not use about or approximately when a figure is exact, or round off the number (i.e. “The city’s population is about 2.25 million”).
Suggestion: The city’s population is 2,245,389.
Label: Style -Large Numbers

Incorrect: Last year, 50–60,000 people attended the event.
Correct: When both numbers in a number range are large round numbers with the same number of digits, do not omit zeros in the first number.
Suggestion: Last year, 50,000–60,000 people attended the event.
Label: Style -Large Numbers

Incorrect: He obtained a master’s degree in Economics.
Correct: Academic subjects are styled in lowercase unless they are proper nouns.
Suggestion: He obtained a master’s degree in economics.
Label: Style -Academic Subjects, Courses, and Lectures

Incorrect: I’m studying for my final for “Literature of the Victorian Era.”
Correct: Course titles are capitalized but not enclosed in quotation marks.
Suggestion: I’m studying for my final for Literature of the Victorian Era.
Label: Style -Academic Subjects, Courses, and Lectures

Incorrect: She attended a lecture called Social Satire in the Works of Charles Dickens.
Correct: Lecture titles are capitalized and enclosed in quotation marks.
Suggestion: She attended a lecture called “Social Satire in the Works of Charles Dickens.”
Label: Style -Academic Subjects, Courses, and Lectures

Incorrect: They’re petitioning to save the Ethnic Studies Department.
Correct: Words in specific names of academic departments are capitalized. This sentence is correct. (However, names similar to the official name are generic, such as “the journalism department” in a reference to the Mass Communication Department.)
Suggestion: They’re petitioning to save the Ethnic Studies Department.
Label: Style -Academic Subjects, Courses, and Lectures

Incorrect: The lecture series “Explorations in Pre-Renaissance European Art” is sold out.
Correct: Names of lecture series are capitalized but not enclosed in quotation marks or italicized.
Suggestion: The lecture series Explorations in Pre-Renaissance European Art is sold out.
Label: Style -Academic Subjects, Courses, and Lectures

Incorrect: Vehicles are classed in various categories (i.e., cars, trucks, and SUVs).
Correct: The abbreviation i.e. is used introduce a clarification; e.g. is used to introduce examples.
Suggestion: Vehicles are classed in various categories (e.g., cars, trucks, and SUVs).
Label: Style -Latinate Abbreviations

Incorrect: Sections of books classified as adventure, comedy, drama, etc. are organized alphabetically.
Correct: The abbreviation etc. is parenthetical and should therefore be framed by a pair of commas when it appears in the middle of a sentence.
Suggestion: Sections of books classified as adventure, comedy, drama, etc., are organized alphabetically.
Label: Style -Latinate Abbreviations

Incorrect: Various weather conditions produce different types of precipitation (e.g., rain, sleet, snow, etc.).
Correct: Another correct revision is “Various weather conditions produce different types of precipitation (rain, sleet, snow, etc.).” The abbreviation e.g. is used to introduce a partial list, and etc. indicates an incomplete list, so they are redundant to each other.
Suggestion: Various weather conditions produce different types of precipitation (e.g., rain, sleet, and snow).
Label: Style -Latinate Abbreviations

Incorrect: It’s not a question of conservative vs. liberal.
Correct: This sentence is correct, though in formal writing, versus is usually spelled out.
Suggestion: It’s not a question of conservative vs. liberal.
Label: Style -Latinate Abbreviations

Incorrect: Samsung, Nokia, et. al. will do well to take note.
Correct: In the phrase et al., al. is an abbreviation of alia, but et is a full word and should not be followed by a period.
Suggestion: Samsung, Nokia, et al. will do well to take note.
Label: Style -Latinate Abbreviations

Incorrect: He works well individually, with partners, or small groups.
Correct: Individually is self-contained, and partners is accompanied by the preposition with, but “small groups” lacks its own preposition.
Suggestion: He works well individually, with partners, or in small groups.
Label: Style -Parallel Sentence Structure

Incorrect: She makes perceptive comments during class discussions, as well as asking good questions.
Correct: The two verbs in this sentence must match in form. (It would be better, however, to also replace “as well as” with and.)
Suggestion: She makes perceptive comments during class discussions, as well as asks good questions.
Label: Style -Parallel Sentence Structure

Incorrect: You see the same advertisers again and again: furniture makers, bathroom-fixtures manufacturers, and high-end kitchen appliances.
Correct: The last item in this list does not conform with the others, because it does not include a noun referring to the product provider.
Suggestion: You see the same advertisers again and again: furniture makers, bathroom-fixtures manufacturers, and makers of high-end kitchen appliances.
Label: Style -Parallel Sentence Structure

Incorrect: Phones needed a quad-core processor and a shiny LED screen and had to be slim and light.
Correct: Items in a list may themselves consist of more than one item; this sentence is correct.
Suggestion: Phones needed a quad-core processor and a shiny LED screen and had to be slim and light.
Label: Style -Parallel Sentence Structure

Incorrect: Lincoln was kept busy, what with waging the Civil War, emancipating slaves, enduring his wife’s eccentricities and his own depression.
Correct: The final item (“his own manic depression”) lacks its own verb, but the absence of a serial comma indicates that the writer meant for what follows slaves to be a single item consisting of two phrases linked with a conjunction (as in the first part of the sentence in the previous example). However, an additional conjunction linking that compound item to the two preceding items is also necessary.
Suggestion: Lincoln was kept busy, what with waging the Civil War, emancipating slaves, and enduring his wife’s eccentricities and his own depression.
Label: Style -Parallel Sentence Structure

Incorrect: Last year, 37 aircraft were retired from the fleet.
Correct: With some exceptions, numbers above one hundred should be in numeral form, and those below one hundred should be spelled out.
Suggestion: Last year, thirty-seven aircraft were retired from the fleet.
Label: Style -Basic Number Rules

Incorrect: The first time the class was offered, 245 students registered for seven sections, and 38 were put on a waiting list.
Correct: When listing numbers referring to the same thing or category of things (such as students, as in this example), use a consistent numeral style, but unrelated numbers should follow the basic style: This sentence is correct.
Suggestion: The first time the class was offered, 245 students registered for seven sections, and 38 were put on a waiting list.
Label: Style -Basic Number Rules

Incorrect: 157 cars were sold on the first day of the sale.
Correct: Numerals should not begin a sentence; spell the number out, or recast the sentence (e.g., “On the first day of the sale, 157 cars were sold.”). Note that and should not separate the place values in a spelled-out number.
Suggestion: One hundred fifty-seven cars were sold on the first day of the sale.
Label: Style -Basic Number Rules

Incorrect: “Myriad” means “many,” but it also is specifically equivalent to 10,000.
Correct: In nontechnical contexts, and in the absence of precise numbers of more than two digits, format round numbers of three or more digits as words
Suggestion: “Myriad” means “many,” but it also is specifically equivalent to ten thousand.
Label: Style -Basic Number Rules

Incorrect: One-hundred twenty-eight books are missing.
Correct: Hyphenate only the words for the tens and ones places.
Suggestion: One hundred twenty-eight books are missing.
Label: Style -Basic Number Rules

Incorrect: Not only did she mimic his voice, but her descriptions were replete with meaning.
Correct: This sentence is merely missing also, recommended in formal writing (“but . . . as well” is an acceptable alternative)
Suggestion: Not only did she mimic his voice, but her descriptions were also replete with meaning.
Label: Style -Not Only… But Also

Incorrect: It became clear that he was describing not only a fantastical land of his imagination but also offering an insight.
Correct: Each of the counterpoints includes a verb, so “not only” must precede the first verb.
Suggestion: It became clear that he was not only describing a fantastical land of his imagination but also offering an insight.
Label: Style -Not Only… But Also

Incorrect: Not only did John bring an inspired sense of focus to the classroom but also embodied that inspired sense of focus.
Correct: John did both things described, so his name should precede “not only.” (Alternatively, punctuation and the replacement of the conjunction but with a pronoun can provide parallel structure: “Not only did John bring an inspired sense of focus to the classroom, he also embodied that inspired sense of focus.”)
Suggestion: John not only brought an inspired sense of focus to the classroom but also embodied that inspired sense of focus.
Label: Style -Not Only… But Also

Incorrect: They’re not only loud but also messy.
Correct: The words describing qualities, loud and messy, are in parallel, one following “not only” and the other preceded by “but also”; this sentence is correct.
Suggestion: They’re not only loud but also messy.
Label: Style -Not Only… But Also

Incorrect: Jane wrote not only a technically detailed and highly informative report but also expressed great environmental awareness.
Correct: As in the second example, the person did two distinct things, so “not only” should precede the first verb.
Suggestion: Jane not only wrote a technically detailed and highly informative report but also expressed great environmental awareness.
Label: Style -Not Only… But Also

Incorrect: The Atlantic ocean separates the Western and Eastern Hemispheres.
Correct: In names of bodies of water, the word for the body of water is generally capitalized. (Although “Western and Eastern Hemispheres” is not the name of a single geographical feature, a convention allows two features that share a designating word to be capitalized as shown.)
Suggestion: The Atlantic Ocean separates the Western and Eastern Hemispheres.
Label: Style -Geographical and Geopolitical Names

Incorrect: Political tensions have abated around the Gulf.
Correct: If the context is clear, certain designations for geographical or geopolitical features can be capitalized in isolation from more specific terms. This sentence is correct.
Suggestion: Political tensions have abated around the Gulf.
Label: Style -Geographical and Geopolitical Names

Incorrect: Nashville is a Mecca for aficionados of country music.
Correct: A place name is not capitalized when it is used metaphorically.
Suggestion: Nashville is a mecca for aficionados of country music.
Label: Style -Geographical and Geopolitical Names

Incorrect: I believe that the Republic will endure.
Correct: Capitalization of generic terms such as republic is a rhetorical flourish and is not recommended for formal writing.
Suggestion: I believe that the republic will endure.
Label: Style -Geographical and Geopolitical Names

Incorrect: The city of Los Angeles ordinance went into effect last year.
Correct: When a municipal designation refers to the governmental body, not the location, capitalize the word city (or town, village, or the like).
Suggestion: The City of Los Angeles ordinance went into effect last year.
Label: Style -Geographical and Geopolitical Names

Incorrect: Mary and John had fostered relationships with government and park officials and were allowed to submit a counterproposal.
Correct: The two verb phrases in this sentence are not intended to be equivalent in emphasis, so the first one should be rendered parenthetical to indicate that the second one contains the key information.
Suggestion: Mary and John, who had fostered relationships with government and park officials, were allowed to submit a counterproposal.
Label: Style -Simplifying Sentences

Incorrect: The incident was tragic all around and should not have played out as it did.
Correct: This revision, by enclosing the note about the incident’s tragedy as a parenthetical, eliminates a weak verb and makes the sentence more concise and focused.
Suggestion: The incident, tragic all around, should not have played out as it did.
Label: Style -Simplifying Sentences

Incorrect: These are annual events that provide members with the opportunity to network and build collaborative relationships.
Correct: Again, deletion of a weak verb (and the associated deletion of that) renders a sentence stronger and more concise.
Suggestion: These annual events provide members with the opportunity to network and build collaborative relationships.
Label: Style -Simplifying Sentences

Incorrect: There is so much that remains to be done.
Correct: Elimination of the expletive “There is” allows for simplification and shortening of this sentence.
Suggestion: So much remains to be done.
Label: Style -Simplifying Sentences

Incorrect: It could lead to genetically inferior and vulnerable animals if inbreeding were to continue.
Correct: This statement is rendered more direct and concise by relocating the key information — continuation of inbreeding — to the head of the sentence as its subject in place of the vague it.
Suggestion: Continued inbreeding could lead to genetically inferior and vulnerable animals.
Label: Style -Simplifying Sentences

Incorrect: For decades, companies have assigned repetitive, manual tasks to robots.
Correct: “For decades, companies have assigned repetitive manual tasks to robots.”
Suggestion: —so the adjectives are noncoordinate and no comma should follow the word

Incorrect: The 218-acre, oceanfront estate is for sale.
Correct: “The 218-acre oceanfront estate is for sale.”
Suggestion: The phrasal adjective “218-acre” modifies “oceanfront estate,” not just , so the adjectives are noncoordinate and no commas are required

Incorrect: A holistic forward-looking, risk-focused, continuous-monitoring approach is often difficult.
Correct: “A holistic forward-looking, risk-focused continuous-monitoring approach is often difficult.” (Also,  modifies everything that follows, so it is noncoordinate and therefore no comma should follow it.)
Suggestion: both describe “continuous-monitoring approach,” and they’re interchangeable, so they are coordinate adjectives and should be separated from each other by a comma. However, “continuous-monitoring” is not equivalent to the other phrases; it is an essential part of the phrase they are modifying, so the final comma is incorrect

Incorrect: Recognizing how a home meets your needs, and the needs of your family, can help you contribute to the development of a happy, healthy, home environment.
Correct: “Recognizing how a home meets your needs, and the needs of your family, can help you contribute to the development of a happy, healthy home environment.”
Suggestion: , it is an intrinsic term describing the type of environment that can be happy and healthy. Those words, which are interchangeable, modify the phrase “home environment,” so the final comma is incorrect

Incorrect: The risks presented by this complex, fragmented, legacy architecture are rarely, if ever, considered.
Correct: “The risks presented by this complex, fragmented legacy architecture are rarely, if ever, considered.”
Suggestion: describe “legacy architecture,” so legacy is not equivalent to the first two words and should not be separated from them. Those words, however, are interchangeable and must be set off by a comma

Incorrect: Phyllis Schlafly, the conservative political activist who devoted much of her energy in the 1970s to stopping the passage of the Equal Rights Amendment that would have banned discrimination on the basis of sex in the United States, has died.
Correct: “Phyllis Schlafly, the conservative political activist who devoted much of her energy in the 1970s to stopping the passage of the Equal Rights Amendment, which would have banned discrimination on the basis of sex in the United States, has died.”
Suggestion: The phrase “The Equal Rights Amendment that would have banned discrimination . . .” implies that more than one such amendment was proposed and that this one in particular, and no others, was intended to ban the specified discrimination. However, “would have banned . . . United States” is helpful but nonessential information about the one and only amendment, and that phrase should be included parenthetically

Incorrect: Smith was referring to the Columbian mammoth which roamed the continent of North America before migrating to the Channel Islands.
Correct: “Smith was referring to the Columbian mammoth, which roamed the continent of North America before migrating to the Channel Islands.”
Suggestion: The sentence seems to imply that more than one species of Columbian mammoth existed, and that the one in question was native to North America but ended up on adjacent islands (with ). However, the phrase “which roamed the continent of North America before migrating to the Channel Islands” is additional information attached to the main clause, “Smith was referring to the Columbian mammoth,” so it should be set off with a comma

Incorrect: The two dwarf planets are in the asteroid belt that’s littered with rocky debris from the formation of the sun and planets some 4.5 billion years ago.
Correct: “The two dwarf planets are in the asteroid belt, which is littered with rocky debris from the formation of the sun and planets some 4.5 billion years ago.”
Suggestion: The implication here is that more than one asteroid belt exists, and the one under discussion is littered with the described rocky debris; one or more others, presumably, has no such detritus. But the part of the sentence that follows “asteroid belt” is nonessential information that should be appended to the main clause parenthetically, with a comma separating the two sentence segments

Incorrect: The rapid and almost ubiquitous deployment of smartphone technologies across the globe has/have put sophisticated technology in the hands of consumers.
Correct: “The rapid and almost ubiquitous deployment of smartphone technologies across the globe has put sophisticated technology in the hands of consumers.”
Suggestion: The multiplicity of nouns preceding —can throw a writer off, but the noun in a prepositional phrase (such as in “of smartphone technologies” or “across the globe”) is irrelevant, so the first in series of nouns in this sentence (“deployment . . . has”) is the pertinent one

Incorrect: There is/are, however, a set of technologies and innovations that have already reached a point where they are robust enough to have real-world applicability.
Correct: “There is, however, a set of technologies and innovations that have already reached a point where they are robust enough to have real-world applicability. (Notice, however, that the subsequent verbs  apply to “technologies and innovations” rather than set, so they are correct in plural form.)
Suggestion: This sentence also features a distracting prepositional phrase, but it follows the key verb, rather than preceding it, as the one in the preceding example does, so the writer may not recognize the applicability of the previously mentioned rule; the pairing is “is . . . a set,” not “are . . . technologies and innovations”

Incorrect: A number of factors have led to the increasing use of technology in relation to regulatory compliance.
Correct: “A number of factors have led to the increasing use of technology in relation to regulatory compliance.”
Suggestion: Note, however, an exception to the rule about the irrelevance of prepositional phrases in noun-verb agreement—when the prepositional phrase follows the phrase “a number”; in that case, the more substantial noun in the prepositional phrase, rather than the vague word , is pertinent

Incorrect: Young people are increasingly accessing news sources on their phones, according to Pew Research Center.
Correct: “Young people are increasingly accessing news sources on their phones, according to the Pew Research Center.”
Suggestion: To test whether an article belongs before a proper name, change the name to a generic reference, such as center in place of “Pew Research Center.” “According to center” does not make sense, so, just as it would be appropriate to insert , insert it before the proper name

Incorrect: Heavens Gate cult committed mass suicides in California in 1997.
Correct: “The Heavens Gate cult committed mass suicide in California in 1997.”
Suggestion: The same test is appropriate in a reference such as this one. “Cult committed mass suicide in California in 1997” works as a headline (where articles are often omitted) but not as a sentence, so insert  before the proper name

Incorrect: Spice Girls topped the music charts seven times.
Correct: “The Spice Girls topped the music charts seven times.” Again, the article is not required if the name modifies a plural noun, as in “Spice Girls songs topped the music charts seven times.”
Suggestion: References to groups of performers should be treated the same way, but only if the name refers to the individuals

Incorrect: Your schedule allows for a fair bit of flexibility.
Correct: your home office, a neighborhood cafe, the beach (so long as your computer doesn’t run out of batteries and the wireless connection isn’t hampered)–anywhere you want. Need a day off? No problem. There is no boss to check in with, and so long as you meet your deadlines and set time to deal with the backlog upon your return, you’re all set.
Suggestion: Because you are essentially working for yourself, the job allows you to write in just about any location

Incorrect: You have a multitude of clients–and can walk away from one if it’s not working with you.
Correct: Yael Grauer is a freelance writer and editor. She also provides proofreading and copyediting services to small businesses and creative entrepreneurs, to help spiff up their e-books, online courses and web copy. Find her at
Suggestion: Most of us have had a boss that made our life miserable at some point in time. I used to dread going to work, and tried to plan my day around avoiding this person. Writing online allows you to work with a multitude of clients, so an occassional bad experience does not ruin your life. You also have the ability to stop working with a client if things aren’t copasetic.

Incorrect: vane / vain / veinAll three sound alike and speakers know what they mean when they say them. The confusion arises with the spellings.CORRECT: A cupola sat astride the angled wedge of the rooftop, sporting a beautiful gold colored weather CORRECT: If we cut one of our 2. having an excessively high opinion of one’s own appearance, attainments, qualities, or possessions: “He is especially vain about his hair.”Neither word is common in ordinary speech. Catholics are familiar with the adjective  “As a politician in a venal age, he preserved his independence and purity.”“The venal man raised the price from $13.50 a pill to $750 overnight.”Although pronounced differently, CORRECT: Polymer solutions are very Both words are pronounced the same. CORRECT: Can a 21-year-old who Both words are pronounced the same by speakers who don’t distinguish between the sounds of CORRECT: I am a grown-up and can make decisions The “The wet dog shook vigorously.”“The oboe player wets his reed before playing.”“Here, whet your sword on this grindstone.” “The scent of baking bread always whets my appetite.”CORRECT: One day in Quebec will Although pronounced differently, the words are frequently mixed up in writing.“Patricia is no longer a hurricane, but it’s about to wreak havoc in Texas.”CORRECT: A tornado The error with these words is failure to recognize “She hung a Christmas wreath on the door.”“Inside, she wreathed the mirrors with holly branches.”CORRECT: Martha Stewart makes small arborvitae Both words are pronounced the same. CORRECT: The Creek Line House: How to Separate Egg Whites from the Yolks
Correct: How To Sew A Shirt CORRECT: How To Sew A Shirt
Suggestion: INCORRECT

Incorrect: give / gift
Correct: “The corporation gifted the university with a million dollars.”  For ordinary purposes, however, it’s still more idiomatic to  presents and not “gift” people with them.
Suggestion: Conservative speakers (like me) shudder to hear both these words used as verbs. as a verb is not new in English. The OED shows citations dated from 1500 to the 1880s.  However, this usage dropped out of general use so long ago that its revival strikes modern ears as barbarous and pompous. I suppose a huge donation to a university might warrant a bit of pomposity

Incorrect: grisly / grizzly
Correct: “The murderer was sentenced to be hanged by the neck until dead.”
Suggestion: The adjective . For example

Incorrect: historic / historical
Correct: “Although fictionalized, the novel is based on well researched historical events.”
Suggestion: The prevailing meaning of  means, “concerned with past events.” It is also used to contrast events that actually happened with fiction or legend

Incorrect: hoard / horde
Correct: The child fled from a horde of angry geese.
Suggestion: The word  originally referred to a tribe of Asiatic nomads. Now it can also mean a large gathering of people or animals.  The word usually bears a connotation of ferocity

Incorrect: home / hone
Correct: Kornblut describes the roadblocks all female candidates must hurdle as “hair, hemlines and husbands.”
Suggestion: The confusion associated with these words occurs when  is “to jump over an obstacle.” It is often used figuratively

Incorrect: Moreover students are expected to read at least one English classic every six weeks.
Correct: is an introductory word and should be followed by a comma.
Suggestion: Moreover, students are expected to read at least one English classic every six weeks.

Incorrect: To become fluent readers students must read outside school hours.
Correct: “To become fluent readers” is an introductory infinitive phrase and should be followed by a comma.
Suggestion: To become fluent readers, students must read outside school hours.

Incorrect: If you want to write well you must be prepared to practice the craft.
Correct: “If you want to write well” is an introductory clause and should be followed by a comma.
Suggestion: If you want to write well, you must be prepared to practice the craft.

Incorrect: Joseph Conrad who was born in Poland began to learn English in his twenties.
Correct: “Who was born in Poland” is a clause that provides nonessential information and should be set off by commas.
Suggestion: Joseph Conrad, who was born in Poland, began to learn English in his twenties.

Incorrect: The boys, who vandalized the public gardens, are in police custody.
Correct: “Who vandalized the public gardens” is essential information because it identifies which boys are meant. It should not be set off by commas.
Suggestion: The boys who vandalized the public gardens are in police custody.

Incorrect: The cougar moved quickly but the tourist reached the safety of the cabin.
Correct: The clauses joined by the conjunction  could stand alone as complete sentences:  “The cougar moved quickly” and “The tourist reached the safety of the cabin.” A comma is not needed with a compound verb joined by a coordinate conjunction: “The tourist saw the cougar and ran to the cabin.”
Suggestion: The cougar moved quickly, but the tourist reached the safety of the cabin.

Incorrect: Circumstances required the children to live in a homeless shelter, nevertheless they kept up with their studies.
Correct: A comma splice results when two main clauses are joined by a comma. The main clauses here are “Circumstances required the children to live in a homeless shelter” and “nevertheless, they kept up with their studies.” The word . A comma splice can be avoided by placing a semicolon after the first clause or by ending the first clause with a period or other end stop and starting a new sentence with a capital.
Suggestion: Circumstances required the children to live in a homeless shelter; nevertheless, they kept up with their studies.

Incorrect: The spelunkers found, that the caves were closed to protect the bats.
Correct: The noun clause is “the caves were closed to protect the bats.” The clause functions as the direct object of the verb in the main clause, .
Suggestion: The spelunkers found that the caves were closed to protect the bats.

Incorrect: The wizard said “Pay no attention to that man behind the curtain.”
Correct: She has three favorite flowers: daffodils, roses, and pansies.
Suggestion: The wizard said, “Pay no attention to that man behind the curtain.”

Incorrect: The rushing waves capsized the boat indifferent gulls wheeled overhead.
Correct: The simplest way to correct a run-on sentence is to put a period at the end of the first clause and capitalize the next one.
Suggestion: The rushing waves capsized the boat. Indifferent gulls wheeled overhead.

Incorrect: Before my astonished eyes, the house sank into the tarn!!!!
Correct: On the rare occasions that an exclamation mark is wanted in formal writing, one is sufficient.
Suggestion: Before my astonished eyes, the house sank into the tarn!

Incorrect: Our staff is required to take three “safety” courses every year.
Correct: In most contexts, placing quotation marks around a word suggests that the word is being used with a meaning other than the obvious one. Writers who enclose words in quotation marks merely for emphasis risk annoying their readers. No one likes to waste time trying to discern a hidden meaning where there is none.
Suggestion: Our staff is required to take three safety courses every year.

Correct: The subject forms  are used as the subject of a verb. Here are models of correct usage:
Suggestion: In the next several weeks,

Incorrect: She made each child feel special by taking pictures and spending quality one on one time
Correct: When the object of a preposition is a pronoun, the object form is required.
Suggestion: She made children feel special by taking pictures and spending quality one on one time

Incorrect: Rodgers then
Correct: When the direct object of a transitive verb is a pronoun, the object form is required. Here is an example of correct usage:
Suggestion: Rodgers then

Incorrect: Susan announces
Correct: . They stand in front of the noun that is “possessed.” For example:
Suggestion: Susan announces

Correct: Pronouns that end in  are called “reflexive pronouns” or “emphatic pronouns.” Here are examples of their correct use:
Suggestion: Both

Incorrect: All the progress we have made to educate people about the hazards of smoking may be for not.
Correct: “All the progress we have made to educate people about the hazards of smoking may be for naught.”
Suggestion: The writer, perhaps unfamiliar with the term , assumed that the last word of the sentence is intended to denote negation rather than futility

Incorrect: President Obama traveled to Cuba for a historical visit.
Correct: “President Obama traveled to Cuba for a historic visit.”
Suggestion: A historical visit is one that occurs in history, though one should not refer to a visit this way;  is superfluous. The writer meant to state that the visit is historic; that word means “of significance to history” (though it sometimes refers simply to something established or existing from the past)

Incorrect: His speech was a load of dribble.
Correct: “His speech was a load of drivel.”
Suggestion: Some people seem to think that references such as the one here are to someone’s writing or utterance being worth no more than drool, but the correct word for foolish or silly talk (which can refer to slavering but is etymologically unrelated) is

Incorrect: The list is virtually a whose-who of prominent community members.
Correct: “The list is virtually a who’s who of prominent community members.” This usage—without a connecting hyphen—stems from publications with titles modeled on the phrase, such as .
Suggestion: The pronoun  has no place in this sentence. The phrase “who’s who” (the contraction is of “who is”) refers to a roster of notable people or things or summaries about them, or to such a group collectively

Incorrect: Where does the US Jewish population predominately live?
Correct: “Where does the US Jewish population predominantly live?”

Incorrect: Measurements should align to business objectives and demonstrate a cause-and-effect relationship when possible.
Correct: “Measurements should align to business objectives and should demonstrate a cause-and-effect relationship when possible.”
Suggestion: The writer assumes that the phrase beginning with , but the sentence can easily be misread as stating that measurements merely should align to business objectives but do in fact demonstrate a cause-and-effect relationship. To clarify that should applies to both phrases, the qualifier should be repeated

Incorrect: This action can affect companies that rely on suppliers in that country to make their products as well as the country’s consumers to buy those products.
Correct: “This action can affect companies that rely on suppliers in that country to make their products as well as rely on the country’s consumers to buy those products.” (Alternatively use a synonym for  instead of repeating it.)
Suggestion: The phrase “make their products as well as” implies that a comparison is being made, rather than that “as well as” is serving as a conjunctive phrase. Also, the distance between the phrase beginning with  and the one beginning with “the country’s consumers” obscures their parallel functions. To clarify the intent of the sentence, repeat the key verb phrase

Incorrect: These reforms have now led to significant adjustments to how short-term credit is provided and the demise of a number of firms operating in this space.
Correct: “These reforms have now led to significant adjustments to how short-term credit is provided and has resulted in the demise of a number of firms operating in this space.”
Suggestion: The phrase “the demise of a number of firms operating in this space” seems abruptly tacked on to this sentence. To clarify that the phrase is parallel to “significant adjustments to how short-term credit is provided,” it could be preceded by . Better yet, launch the last part of the sentence with a more thorough linking phrase

Incorrect: What If Dave Roberts Didn’t Steal 2nd Base?
Correct: Dave Roberts is a baseball player. This headline references a game played in 2004. As Roberts did, in fact, steal the base, the correct verb for the “if clause” is “hadn’t stolen,” not “didn’t steal.”
Suggestion: What If Dave Roberts
Label: Verb -Didn’t With Conditional

Incorrect: She probably would have lived to 90 if this didn’t happen.
Correct: This line of dialogue is from a movie in which a young woman has been murdered. As the woman is dead and cannot live to be 90, the correct verb for the “if clause” is “hadn’t happened.”
Suggestion: She probably would have lived to 90 if this

Incorrect: But imagine if I didn’t have access to health insurance through my job.
Correct: The original statement is from a blog entry in which a man tells how he survived a serious illness because he did, in fact, have access to adequate health insurance at the time. The correct verb form for the “if clause,” therefore, is “hadn’t had.”

Suggestion: If Brian Epstein
Label: Verb -Didn’t With Conditional

Incorrect: What would have happened if the Titanic didn’t sink?

Incorrect: Being that you’re an industry expert, I was hoping
Correct: We are hoping someone could tell us if this resort has a lively crowd and if it is too far from the main strip.

Incorrect: I’m hoping
Correct: The “hoping if” error may arise from the fact that the writer politely wishes to acknowledge the uncertainty of a favorable reply, not realizing that the word  in itself is sufficient to express uncertainty.

Incorrect: French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius Tuesday urged the European Union (EU) to arm Iraqi Kurds to fight Islamist militants
Correct: The verb “to overrun” is conjugated the same as the verb “to run”: .
Suggestion: French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius Tuesday urged the European Union (EU) to arm Iraqi Kurds to fight Islamist militants

Incorrect: Earlier, one group of over 100 protesters lapped Columbus Circle, and then walked to the Apple store on Fifth Avenue. They
Correct: The distinction between the verbs .

Incorrect: But New Mexico authorities
Correct: When certain verbs are completed by an infinitive, the bare form (without the .

Correct: Ordinarily,  appears only in the main clause and not in the if clause.

Correct: This conditional sentence contains two errors: 1. “Had of” is a miswriting for “had have.” 2. The addition of a  in the if clause is not needed.
Label: Verb -Mixed Errors

Incorrect: The principal gave the award to the girl whom, as we later learned, is his daughter.
Correct: The adjective clause is .
Suggestion: The principal gave the award to the girl who, as we later learned, is his daughter.

Incorrect: His resignation played a factor in the controversy.
Correct: An action can play a role regarding another action, or it can be a factor, but “played a factor” is a mixed metaphor.
Suggestion: His resignation was a factor in the controversy.Alterna.: His resignation played a role in the controversy.
Label: Vocabulary -Idiomatic Expressions

Incorrect: She’s simply grasping for straws.
Correct: This expression means that one is making a desperate attempt as if trying to get a hold on something substantial but ending up with only straws in one’s hands, not that one is trying to get a hold on straws.
Suggestion: She’s simply grasping at straws.
Label: Vocabulary -Idiomatic Expressions

Incorrect: His compliment was a real boost in the arm for my confidence.
Correct: One can get a boost from a shot in the arm (if the injection provides energy), but “boost in the arm” doesn’t make sense.
Suggestion: His compliment was a real shot in the arm for my confidence.
Label: Vocabulary -Idiomatic Expressions

Incorrect: With all do respect, I disagree.
Correct: This expression refers to respect that is due, not “doing” respect, in the sense of demonstrating it.
Suggestion: With all due respect, I disagree.
Label: Vocabulary -Idiomatic Expressions

Incorrect: That description fits you to a tee.
Correct: This expression, whose origin is uncertain, refers to the letter T (or perhaps something with that shape), not to the spike on which a golf ball is placed or anything else spelled tee.
Suggestion: That description fits you to a T.
Label: Vocabulary -Idiomatic Expressions

Incorrect: He said he’d touch bases with me tomorrow.
Correct: The other person is touching just one base — that of the person he is contacting.
Suggestion: He said he’d touch base with me tomorrow.
Label: Vocabulary -Idiomatic Expressions

Incorrect: I remember how I used to wile away the hours during summer vacation.
Correct: The expression “while away” refers to passage of time, not to trickery, which is the meaning of wile.
Suggestion: I remember how I used to while away the hours during summer vacation.
Label: Vocabulary -Idiomatic Expressions

Incorrect: She awaited the news with baited breath.
Correct: One’s breath is not baited, as if set up to be caught; it is bated (the word is a shortened form of abated), meaning “restrained.”
Suggestion: She awaited the news with bated breath.
Label: Vocabulary -Idiomatic Expressions

Incorrect: We found ourselves in dire straights.
Correct: The expression “dire straits” refers to difficulty, not an undeviating line.
Suggestion: We found ourselves in dire straits.
Label: Vocabulary -Idiomatic Expressions

Incorrect: The gophers are wrecking havoc with my garden.
Correct: Although havoc can involve wreckage, havoc is not wrecked; it’s wreaked, or caused.
Suggestion: The gophers are wreaking havoc with my garden.
Label: Vocabulary -Idiomatic Expressions

Incorrect: Who was the behind the scenes negotiator who facilitated the deal?
Correct: “Who was the behind-the-scenes negotiator who facilitated the deal?”
Suggestion: The negotiator is described as working behind the scenes. When that phrase appears in isolation, as an adverbial phrase rather than as a phrasal adjective modifying a noun that follows, no hyphenation is needed, but here, it serves the latter function

Incorrect: There is no “one size fits all” list of risk concerns.
Correct: “There is no one-size-fits-all list of risk concerns.”
Suggestion: Enclosing a phrase like this implies that the phrase is obscure and requires scare quotes or that someone said it and so quotation marks are needed, but the expression is ubiquitous, and no speaker is alluded to. To signal that those four words combine to modify , string them together with several hyphens

Incorrect: Jones was forced out-of-bounds on the deciding play.
Correct: “Jones was forced out of bounds on the deciding play.”
Suggestion: The adverbial phrase “out of bounds” requires no linkage to indicate that it is self-contained; it modifies the verb it follows, not a subsequent noun

Incorrect: She has an annoying in your face attitude.
Correct: “She has an annoying in-your-face attitude.”
Suggestion: The phrase “in your face” modifies  as a single unit, so the phrase should be hyphenated

Incorrect: It has recently become a most-favored-nation among many countries in the European Union.
Correct: “It has recently become a most-favored nation among many countries in the European Union.” ( joins the hyphenation train only when it loses its noun status and joins the phrasal adjective to modify another noun, as in “most-favored-nation status.”)
Suggestion: When “most-favored nation” appears in isolation, it should appear just as it does within the quotation marks in this explanatory sentence; “most favored” is a phrasal adjective modifying

Incorrect: Journalists are like dogs, when ever anything moves they begin to bark.
Correct: She smiles at me whenever I see her.
Suggestion: Journalists are like dogs, whenever anything moves they begin to bark.

Incorrect: The computer crashes when ever I try to game.
Correct: The words  are written separately when the sense is “when, if ever?”
Suggestion: The computer crashes whenever I try to game.

Incorrect: As I finished reading the letter, I came to the realization that I had misinterpreted all his actions.
Correct: 2.Original: Their employer said three workers would be laid off due to the fact that sales had declined.Correct : Their employer said three workers would be laid off because sales had declined.
Suggestion: As I finished reading the letter, I realized that I had misinterpreted all his actions.
Label: Writing -Wordiness

Incorrect: At that point in time the ship had entered the most dangerous part of the passage.
Correct: 4.Original: I want you to take my dog in the event that I must remain hospitalized.Correct : I want you to take my dog if I must remain hospitalized.
Suggestion: Then the ship had entered the most dangerous part of the passage.
Label: Writing -Wordiness

Incorrect: Regardless of the fact that we have been friends for thirty years, I must report this to the police.
Correct: No related posts.
Suggestion: Although we have been friends for thirty years, I must report this to the police.
Label: Writing -Wordiness

Incorrect: Faith Hope is Executive Director at the Charity Foundation.
Correct: When a job or office title follows the bearer’s name, it is almost invariably not capitalized.
Suggestion: Faith Hope is executive director at the Charity Foundation.
Label: Writing -Job and Office Titles

Incorrect: John Doe is the Roberta Roe Professor of Anthropology at Oxford.
Correct: Titles for holders of endowed professorships are capitalized in all references; this sentence was originally correct.
Suggestion: John Doe is the Roberta Roe Professor of Anthropology at Oxford.
Label: Writing -Job and Office Titles

Incorrect: Former Vice President Al Gore is an author and an environmental activist.
Correct: When an adjective precedes a job or office title, the title is also treated as a description and is not capitalized.
Suggestion: Former vice president Al Gore is an author and an environmental activist.
Label: Writing -Job and Office Titles

Incorrect: The evening’s highlight was a talk by Economist Adam Smith.
Correct: Words that identify a person’s occupation or role but are not specific titles are not capitalized.
Suggestion: The evening’s highlight was a talk by economist Adam Smith.
Label: Writing -Job and Office Titles

Incorrect: The first lady will attend the event.
Correct: Honorifics (also including “Your Honor,” “Her Royal Highness,” and the like) should always be capitalized.
Suggestion: The First Lady will attend the event.
Label: Writing -Job and Office Titles

Incorrect: Working with such close friends as these three were could have been problematic.
Correct: Presuming that the people referred to are still friends, the linking verb should be in the present tense.
Suggestion: Working with such close friends as these three are could have been problematic.
Label: Writing -Consistency of Verb Tense

Incorrect: My visit to Yellowstone National Park was the most enjoyable vacation I’ve ever had.
Correct: Even though the visit is in the past, it is still, as explicitly stated in the sentence, the person’s most enjoyable vacation, so the linking verb should be is.
Suggestion: My visit to Yellowstone National Park is the most enjoyable vacation I’ve ever had.
Label: Writing -Consistency of Verb Tense

Incorrect: She didn’t even know that Tuvan throat singing existed.
Correct: Tuvan throat singing is extant, so the final verb should be in the present tense.
Suggestion: She didn’t even know that Tuvan throat singing exists.
Label: Writing -Consistency of Verb Tense

Incorrect: He was especially interested in how binaural recording worked.
Correct: The technology described still works, so the verb after that phrase should be works.
Suggestion: He was especially interested in how binaural recording works.
Label: Writing -Consistency of Verb Tense

Incorrect: They wanted to know how the policy benefited the company.
Correct: Sometimes, whether a verb should be in the present tense or the past tense depends on the context. In this case, if the policy still benefits the company, the final verb in this sentence should be benefits. If the benefit was temporary, the sentence is correct as is.
Suggestion: They wanted to know how the policy benefited the company.
Label: Writing -Consistency of Verb Tense
